[3, 14] This approach offers a powerful, top-down perspective, capable of quantifying changes in forest cover, water quality, urban expansion, and industrial heat signatures with remarkable granularity. [2, 20] This is a distinctly different paradigm from the West's bottom-up approach, which largely relies on corporate self-disclosure, a thicket of competing standards, and the Herculean task of aggregating disparate national data.

There is little doubt that China’s progress in certain environmental domains is both real and globally significant. Beijing's industrial might has been ruthlessly re-tooled to dominate the green-technology sector. The country's breakneck expansion of renewable energy capacity is a case in point. By early 2024, China's installed capacity of wind and solar power had reportedly surpassed that of coal, a symbolic milestone. The nation’s broader policy architecture, from the overarching "dual-carbon" targets—peaking emissions by 2030 and achieving carbon neutrality by 2060—to the new mandatory sustainability disclosure rules for listed companies introduced in the spring of 2024, signals a seriousness of intent that few other nations can muster. [4] This state-led blitz has had tangible effects, not least in driving down the global cost of solar panels and wind turbines, thereby making the green transition more affordable for everyone. [11]

In stark contrast, the global picture is one of paralysis. The 2024 edition of the *Sustainable Development Report*, an independent global assessment, corroborates the bleak 16-17% figure, noting that worldwide progress has stagnated since 2020. [27, 39] The report attributes this inertia to the lingering effects of the COVID-19 pandemic, armed conflicts, and a strained international financial system. [27, 36, 41] Where China can command, the world must cajole. Global progress is the messy, slow-moving product of 193 sovereign nations attempting to coordinate voluntary actions. The very structure of international cooperation seems ill-suited to the speed and scale required, a weakness that China's autocratic efficiency ruthlessly exposes.

Yet, the satellite's gaze, for all its power, is not all-seeing. The CBAS methodology is naturally skewed towards metrics that can be observed from orbit. This creates a significant blind spot. The 17 SDGs are a holistic framework, encompassing not only environmental goals but also critical social and governance targets. SDG 16, for instance, calls for promoting "peace, justice and strong institutions," and includes targets on press freedom—a metric on which global progress has notably reversed. [27] SDG 8 targets decent work and economic growth. These are dimensions of sustainability that a satellite cannot measure. They rely on on-the-ground data, civil-society audits, and a free press, areas where China's record is notoriously poor.

The 60.5% figure, therefore, likely reflects a definition of "sustainability" that is heavily weighted towards the 'E' in ESG, while downplaying the 'S' and the 'G'. It measures the physical world—new forests, cleaner rivers, sprawling solar farms—with great accuracy. It cannot, however, measure the quality of governance, the fairness of labour practices, or the robustness of civil liberties. This is not merely a methodological quibble; it is a fundamental redefinition of sustainability itself, tailored to the strengths of an authoritarian state and its preferred technological tools.

This selective measurement is most glaring in the context of China's paradoxical energy policy. While the country is the world's undisputed renewables champion, it remains deeply committed to coal as a backstop for energy security. [18] Even as new solar and wind farms come online at a record pace, new coal-fired power plants are still being approved and built. This duality is a core contradiction. A holistic view of sustainability would have to heavily penalize this continued investment in the dirtiest of fossil fuels, but a data model focused on the *rate of change* in green energy installation may well produce a positive score.

Furthermore, the provenance of the data invites caution. CBAS is a national institution, fulfilling a commitment made by President Xi Jinping. [3] While it presents its work as a scientific contribution to the global good, its objectives are inevitably aligned with those of the Chinese state. Without full transparency of its algorithms and the ability for international researchers to independently replicate its findings, the 60.5% figure remains a black box. It is a claim that must be trusted, not a result that can be verified.

The implications for global business and geopolitics are profound. First, China is not just aiming for green leadership; it is actively shaping the global definition of what it means to be sustainable. It is presenting a competing model to the Western, stakeholder-capitalism approach—one that is state-driven, technologically monitored, and less concerned with the intangible elements of governance and human rights. This techno-utilitarian model will be attractive to other developing nations who may see it as a faster path to decarbonisation, unencumbered by the messy debates of liberal democracies.

For international corporations and investors, navigating this landscape requires a nuanced understanding. The opportunities presented by China's green boom are immense. However, the risks are equally significant. Relying on state-produced sustainability metrics like those from CBAS could obscure deep-seated risks in supply chains, from forced labour to poor governance, that a satellite will never detect. The implementation of China's new corporate disclosure rules from 2025 onwards will be a critical test. Will they align with emerging global baselines like those from the International Sustainability Standards Board (ISSB), fostering genuine transparency, or will they serve to reinforce the state's narrative? [4, 22]

Ultimately, the CBAS data is a mirror reflecting China's broader strengths and weaknesses. The country's capacity for long-term planning and massive industrial mobilisation is achieving remarkable, tangible results in the energy transition. The world has much to learn from its ability to deploy capital and technology at scale. However, the impressive 60.5% figure is not an objective measure of holistic sustainability. It is the product of a specific worldview, one that sees progress through the unblinking eye of a satellite and prioritises the quantifiable, physical realm over the complex, often inconvenient, realities of social and political life. While China may indeed be winning a race, it is a race whose finish line it has defined for itself.

title: "Blue Recovery": The APEC Ocean and Fisheries Working Group Report
excerpt: APEC's ambitious "Blue Recovery" agenda, while comprehensive in its aims to tackle illegal fishing and marine debris, risks being undermined by a lack of binding commitments, the persistence of harmful fisheries subsidies, and an inadequate response to the overarching threat of climate change.
body:
### The Shallows of Ambition: APEC's "Blue Recovery" Navigates Troubled Waters

**A laudable, if overdue, sense of urgency is pervading the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum's discussions on the marine environment. After a decade-long hiatus, the recent 5th APEC Ocean-Related Ministerial Meeting (AOMM5) in Busan, South Korea, signaled a renewed political commitment to the vast Pacific Ocean that both connects and sustains its 21 member economies. The communiqué, framed around the aspirational theme of “Navigating our Blue Future – Connection, Innovation, and Prosperity,” lays out a vision for a "Blue Recovery"—an economic rebound from recent global disruptions that is intrinsically linked to the sustainable use of ocean resources. Yet, a closer examination of the APEC Ocean and Fisheries Working Group (OFWG) report and associated documents reveals a strategy that, while comprehensive in scope, may prove perilously shallow in execution. The rhetoric of a sustainable and inclusive blue economy is powerful, but it risks foundering on the rocks of uneven implementation, national interest, and the monumental scale of the challenges ahead.**

At the heart of the OFWG's blueprint for a Blue Recovery are a series of roadmaps targeting the most egregious threats to the region's marine ecosystems and the economies that depend on them. Foremost among these is the persistent scourge of Illegal, Unreported, and Unregulated (IUU) fishing. This is not merely a matter of a few rogue trawlers; IUU fishing is a systemic problem that strips an estimated $10 billion to $23.5 billion annually from the global economy, with the Asia-Pacific region being a significant contributor to this loss. It undermines sustainable fisheries management, jeopardizes food security for millions, and is frequently linked to other transnational crimes, including human trafficking. APEC’s commitment to combating IUU fishing through enhanced monitoring, control, and surveillance is, therefore, a critical pillar of its Blue Recovery agenda. The promotion of data-driven approaches, including satellite monitoring and artificial intelligence, is a welcome acknowledgment of the technological tools available to tackle this menace.

However, the effectiveness of these measures hinges entirely on the political will of member economies to cooperate and enforce them. The APEC framework is, by design, non-binding. While roadmaps and ministerial declarations provide a common direction, they lack the teeth of international law. The success of initiatives like the Port State Measures Agreement (PSMA), a potentially potent tool to prevent illegally caught fish from entering the market, depends on widespread ratification and rigorous, coordinated implementation. As of early 2025, several key APEC economies have yet to ratify or fully implement the PSMA, creating significant loopholes that IUU operators can exploit. The OFWG’s strategy is long on capacity-building workshops and the sharing of best practices, but short on mechanisms to ensure compliance. Until there are tangible consequences for non-compliance, the fight against IUU fishing risks being a perpetual game of cat and mouse, with regional prosperity paying the price.

A second major focus of the Blue Recovery is the escalating crisis of marine debris. The images of coastlines choked with plastic waste are a potent symbol of a linear economic model that has treated the ocean as a limitless dump. APEC’s Roadmap on Marine Debris rightly calls for a multi-pronged approach, from improved waste management on land to the development of innovative solutions for plastic recycling and upcycling. This is an area where public-private partnerships, another cornerstone of the APEC approach, could yield significant results. The private sector, facing increasing consumer and regulatory pressure, has a vested interest in developing more sustainable packaging and contributing to a circular economy. APEC can and should act as a facilitator for these partnerships, fostering a regulatory environment that encourages investment in green technologies.

Yet, the sheer scale of the marine debris problem dwarfs current efforts. The Asia-Pacific region, with its rapidly growing coastal populations and manufacturing hubs, is a major source of global plastic pollution. Addressing this requires a fundamental shift in production and consumption patterns, a challenge that extends far beyond the remit of the OFWG. While APEC’s focus on waste management is a necessary step, it is akin to mopping the floor while the tap is still running. A truly sustainable Blue Recovery necessitates a more profound engagement with the principles of a circular economy, including extended producer responsibility and the reduction of single-use plastics at their source. The OFWG’s current roadmap is a commendable start, but it must be seen as just that—a starting point for a much more ambitious and integrated regional strategy.

The concept of a “blue economy,” as championed by APEC, is seductively broad. It encompasses not only traditional sectors like fisheries and tourism but also emerging industries such as marine renewable energy, biotechnology, and sustainable aquaculture. APEC’s vision is one where economic growth is decoupled from environmental degradation. This is a compelling narrative, and one that aligns with global sustainability goals. The emphasis on supporting small-scale fisheries and aquaculture, and on empowering women in the marine sector, is particularly noteworthy. These communities are often the most vulnerable to the impacts of environmental degradation and have the most to gain from a transition to a more sustainable model.

However, the term “blue economy” is at risk of becoming a catch-all phrase, a victim of its own success. Without clear definitions and robust sustainability criteria, there is a danger that it could be co-opted to justify “business as usual” under a new, more environmentally friendly guise. The development of sustainable aquaculture, for instance, holds immense promise for food security, but it must be managed carefully to avoid the environmental pitfalls of its land-based counterpart, such as pollution and the destruction of coastal habitats. Similarly, the exploitation of marine mineral resources or the development of large-scale marine renewable energy projects must be subject to rigorous environmental impact assessments and be guided by the precautionary principle.

A significant blind spot in APEC's Blue Recovery discourse is the vexed issue of fisheries subsidies. The World Trade Organization has for years been wrestling with the challenge of eliminating subsidies that contribute to overfishing and overcapacity. These subsidies, which often flow to large industrial fishing fleets, create a perverse incentive to harvest fish at unsustainable levels, undermining the very resource base upon which the blue economy depends. While APEC ministers have paid lip service to the need to address harmful subsidies, the OFWG’s work plan lacks a clear and time-bound commitment to their elimination. This is a glaring omission. A genuine Blue Recovery cannot be built on a foundation of economic policies that actively encourage the depletion of fish stocks. APEC, as a forum dedicated to promoting free and open trade, is uniquely positioned to take a leading role in this area. Its failure to do so thus far speaks to the powerful domestic constituencies that benefit from the status quo.

Another area where APEC's ambitions may fall short is in the realm of marine conservation. The APEC Marine Sustainable Development Report highlights the importance of marine protected areas (MPAs) and other area-based conservation measures. These are essential tools for safeguarding biodiversity, rebuilding fish stocks, and enhancing the resilience of marine ecosystems to climate change. However, the designation of MPAs is often a contentious process, pitting conservation goals against the interests of commercial fishing and other extractive industries. APEC’s commitment to expanding MPA coverage is welcome, but it must be accompanied by a focus on effective management. A “paper park,” an area that is designated as protected but lacks the resources and political will for effective enforcement, is of little ecological value. The OFWG should prioritize the development of best practices for MPA management and create mechanisms for sharing knowledge and expertise among member economies.

The overarching challenge that looms over all of APEC’s Blue Recovery efforts is, of course, climate change. Rising sea levels, ocean acidification, and the increasing frequency and intensity of extreme weather events pose an existential threat to coastal communities and marine ecosystems across the Asia-Pacific. APEC acknowledges this threat and calls for enhanced cooperation on climate adaptation and resilience. Yet, there is a curious disconnect between this acknowledgment and the forum’s broader economic agenda. APEC remains, at its core, an organization dedicated to promoting economic growth and trade liberalization. While there is a growing recognition that this growth must be sustainable, there has been a reluctance to confront the hard trade-offs that may be necessary to achieve deep decarbonization.

A Blue Recovery that does not fully integrate climate considerations is doomed to fail. This means not only investing in coastal resilience and climate-smart fisheries but also ensuring that APEC’s trade and investment policies are aligned with the goals of the Paris Agreement. It means phasing out subsidies for fossil fuels, which continue to drive both climate change and overfishing, and promoting investment in renewable energy. These are politically difficult conversations, but they are essential if APEC is to navigate a truly sustainable blue future.

In conclusion, the APEC Ocean and Fisheries Working Group has crafted a comprehensive and ambitious agenda for a Blue Recovery. The renewed focus on ocean governance is a significant and welcome development. However, the success of this agenda will not be measured in the number of roadmaps adopted or ministerial declarations signed. It will be measured in the tangible improvements to the health of the Pacific Ocean and the well-being of the communities that depend on it. This will require a level of political will, regional cooperation, and long-term commitment that has, thus far, been elusive.

The incisive edge of skepticism is warranted here. APEC’s consensus-based approach, while inclusive, can also be a recipe for inaction. The path to a genuine Blue Recovery is fraught with challenges, from the entrenched interests of industrial fishing fleets to the daunting complexities of climate change. Navigating these challenges will require more than just a shared vision; it will require bold leadership, difficult choices, and a willingness to hold member economies accountable. The OFWG has provided a map; it is now up to the leaders of the APEC economies to decide whether they have the courage to follow it into deeper, more sustainable waters.

title: Internal Management Challenges for Corporate Sustainability Action in China
excerpt: As China's green ambitions intensify, the real barrier to corporate sustainability lies not in policy, but within the firms themselves, where a chasm between boardroom rhetoric and operational reality persists due to flawed governance, misaligned incentives, and a critical lack of internal capacity.
body:
### China’s Green Wall: The Internal Management Impasse in Corporate Sustainability

BEIJING AND HONG KONG—As 2023 draws to a close, a palpable tension defines China's corporate sustainability landscape. On one hand, Beijing’s ambitious “dual carbon” goals—peaking emissions before 2030 and achieving carbon neutrality by 2060—have cascaded down through the political and economic apparatus with unmistakable force. On the other, a significant and stubborn gap persists between the rhetoric of sustainability embraced in corporate boardrooms and its substantive implementation within the labyrinthine structures of Chinese firms. While external pressures from the government, investors, and international markets are mounting, the real battle for sustainability in China is being fought—and often lost—within the companies themselves. A host of deep-seated internal management challenges, from misaligned governance and incentive structures to a sheer lack of execution capacity, form a great wall of their own, hindering the translation of green ambitions into meaningful action.

At the apex of the corporate structure, the problem begins with a disconnect in governance. A 2022/2023 survey by the United Nations Development Programme and PwC revealed a telling statistic: while 61% of surveyed Chinese enterprises reported that a low-carbon transition had been a subject of board-level discussion, a mere 30.3% had established concrete carbon targets. This speaks to a broader issue of accountability. The inclusion of sustainability on the agenda is a nod to political and market pressures, but the failure to codify this into measurable objectives suggests a lack of genuine strategic integration. For many boards, sustainability remains a matter of compliance or public relations, rather than a core component of long-term value creation. The internal mechanisms for oversight and management responsibility are, as of now, frequently underdeveloped.

The structure of corporate governance in China, with its unique interplay of state influence and market forces, further complicates matters. In state-owned enterprises (SOEs), which represent a significant portion of the economy and a high rate of ESG disclosure, government policy is a primary driver of action. Yet, this can lead to a compliance-oriented mindset, where sustainability initiatives are pursued to meet state directives rather than being driven by an internal logic of risk management and opportunity. In private firms, the picture is more varied. While many are agile and innovative, they often lack the resources and capacity to implement comprehensive sustainability strategies, and the disclosure rate for ESG reports among private companies has been significantly lower than for their state-owned counterparts. Moreover, the influence of concentrated ownership structures can be a double-edged sword; while it can drive decisive action, it may also lead to a focus on short-term economic performance at the expense of longer-term environmental and social considerations if the controlling shareholders are not aligned with sustainability goals.

#### The Frozen Middle: Managerial and Employee Disconnect

Below the boardroom, the “frozen middle”—middle management—presents a formidable obstacle. These are the managers tasked with translating high-level strategy into operational reality. However, they are often caught between the board's nascent green pronouncements and a set of entrenched key performance indicators (KPIs) that prioritize production targets, cost control, and short-term profitability. Without a fundamental rewiring of these incentive structures, sustainability will invariably be relegated to a secondary concern. Research has indicated that aligning executive compensation with sustainability goals is a powerful driver of performance, yet this practice remains far from standard in China. The lack of clear internal management documents and functional departments dedicated to promoting Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) further exacerbates this implementation gap, leaving managers without a clear mandate or the necessary tools.

Employee engagement, a critical engine for any successful corporate transformation, is another area of significant challenge. While there is growing awareness of environmental issues among the populace, translating this into proactive, pro-environmental behavior within the corporate setting is not automatic. Effective engagement requires more than just top-down directives; it necessitates fostering a corporate culture where sustainability is a shared value. This involves clear communication, training, and empowering employees to contribute to sustainability initiatives. However, many Chinese firms, particularly in more traditional, hierarchical sectors, struggle with the kind of open, participatory culture that allows such bottom-up innovation to flourish. The focus remains on operational efficiency, and without explicit mechanisms to solicit and reward employee contributions to sustainability, a vast reservoir of potential remains untapped.

#### The Data Deficit and Supply Chain Opacity

The effective management of sustainability is predicated on the availability of reliable data. Here, Chinese firms face a significant hurdle. The lack of a unified, mandatory ESG reporting framework (as of late 2023) has resulted in a patchwork of disclosure standards. While the number of firms issuing ESG reports is on the rise, the quality and comparability of this data are often poor. This is not merely an external reporting issue; it reflects a deeper, internal challenge of data collection and management. Many companies simply do not have the systems in place to accurately track their environmental and social impact across complex operations. This data deficit hampers informed decision-making, risk assessment, and the setting of credible performance targets.

This challenge is magnified when considering supply chains. For many Chinese manufacturers, the bulk of their environmental and social impact lies not within their own factory walls, but distributed across vast and often opaque networks of suppliers (Scope 3 emissions). While there is a growing recognition of the need for sustainable supply chain management, progress is slow. Key challenges include a lack of transparency and a lack of trust between firms and their suppliers. Establishing collaborative, rather than purely transactional, relationships with suppliers is essential for driving sustainability improvements, but this requires a significant investment in training, information sharing, and joint goal-setting—a step many firms are hesitant to take. Without robust internal systems to monitor and manage supplier ESG performance, corporate sustainability claims can amount to little more than greenwashing.

#### Navigating the Path Forward: From Compliance to Competitive Advantage

Looking ahead, the internal management landscape for corporate sustainability in China is set for a period of profound, albeit challenging, transformation. The impending move towards a mandatory and more standardized ESG disclosure system will force a greater degree of internal rigor. Companies will no longer be able to treat sustainability as a peripheral activity. They will need to invest in the internal infrastructure—the people, processes, and technology—to manage and report on their performance effectively.

Overcoming these internal hurdles will require a multi-faceted approach. Boards must move beyond mere discussion to embed sustainability into corporate strategy, with clear targets and accountability mechanisms. Incentive structures for senior and middle management must be reformed to reflect sustainability objectives. Significant investment in capacity building is needed, not only for dedicated sustainability professionals but across all business functions. This includes training in data collection and analysis, sustainable supply chain management, and fostering a culture of environmental stewardship. Finally, firms must recognize that the state, while a powerful driver of the agenda, cannot solve these internal challenges. The impetus for building genuine, integrated sustainability capabilities must come from within.

The task is daunting. Yet, the firms that successfully navigate this transition will not only be compliant with the evolving regulatory landscape but will also unlock significant competitive advantages. They will be better equipped to manage climate-related risks, attract and retain talent, innovate in resource efficiency, and build more resilient supply chains. The story of corporate sustainability in China in the coming years will be one of internal transformation. For those that manage to break down their own internal walls, the rewards will be substantial, aligning their own long-term interests with the nation's ambitious green future.

title: The Global Development Initiative (GDI) and Global Partnerships
excerpt: More than a simple rebranding of foreign aid, China's Global Development Initiative represents a calculated pivot from the Belt and Road's heavy infrastructure to a more nuanced, patient strategy aimed at fundamentally reshaping the global order and winning the allegiance of the Global South.
body:
### The Global Development Initiative: China’s Patient Play for Global Influence

BEIJING - In the grand theatre of global power politics, grand pronouncements are commonplace. Yet, China's Global Development Initiative (GDI), unveiled by President Xi Jinping at the United Nations General Assembly in September 2021, warrants closer inspection. More than mere diplomatic rhetoric, the GDI, particularly when viewed alongside its younger siblings—the Global Security Initiative (GSI) and the Global Civilization Initiative (GCI)—represents a quiet but calculated recalibration of China's foreign policy. It signals a shift away from the debt-laden, large-scale infrastructure projects that defined the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) towards a more nuanced, arguably more sustainable, and ultimately more ambitious strategy for reshaping the global order.

As of late 2023, the world finds itself at a developmental crossroads. The lingering economic scars of the COVID-19 pandemic, coupled with geopolitical tensions and a widening North-South gap, have stalled progress on the UN's 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development (SDGs). It is into this breach that China has stepped, positioning the GDI as a timely and necessary intervention to refocus the international community on the core issue of development. The initiative's eight priority areas—poverty alleviation, food security, pandemic response, development financing, climate change, industrialization, digital economy, and connectivity—are shrewdly aligned with the SDGs, making it an attractive proposition for developing nations.

This deliberate alignment has paid dividends. By the close of 2023, over 100 countries and numerous international organizations had voiced their support for the GDI, with nearly 70 nations joining the 'Group of Friends of the GDI' at the UN. For many in the Global South, weary of conditional aid and what they perceive as the lecturing tone of Western donors, the GDI's emphasis on partnership, South-South cooperation, and respect for national sovereignty is a welcome change. The initiative's core tenets—a people-centered approach, benefits for all, and innovation-driven development—are hard to argue with on paper.

#### A Tactical Retreat from the BRI?

The timing of the GDI's launch was not coincidental. It arrived as the BRI, Mr. Xi's signature foreign policy project of the previous decade, was losing momentum. Dogged by accusations of creating 'debt traps' for recipient nations, a lack of transparency, and projects that often served China's strategic interests more than local development needs, the BRI's reputation had become tarnished. Compounded by China's own economic slowdown and the fiscal pressures of its zero-COVID policy, the appetite for bankrolling multi-billion dollar infrastructure loans had diminished.

The GDI, in contrast, is a more financially modest and politically astute undertaking. It prioritizes smaller, 'small yet smart' projects that are often grant-based rather than loan-financed. This shift is managed by the China International Development Cooperation Agency (CIDCA), an entity established in 2018 to centralize and professionalize the country's foreign aid efforts. CIDCA's role in managing a 'Global Development Project Pool' and a 'Global Development Capital Pool' suggests a more structured and potentially more transparent approach than the often-diffuse implementation of the BRI. By late 2022, this project pool already contained over 100 projects, with China pledging a significant, albeit not BRI-level, financial commitment through an upgraded Global Development and South-South Cooperation Fund, which now totals $4 billion.

This move towards smaller, more targeted development projects also serves to address the criticism that Chinese aid is often divorced from genuine human rights and governance concerns. By focusing on tangible outcomes like food security, public health, and poverty reduction, China can build goodwill and cultivate a positive image as a responsible global actor, without attaching the political conditionalities that often accompany Western aid. It is a form of soft power projection that is both cost-effective and difficult to counter directly.

#### The GDI, GSI, and GCI Trinity: A New Global Governance Architecture

To view the GDI in isolation, however, is to miss the forest for the trees. It is the crucial economic pillar of a broader strategic triumvirate, alongside the Global Security Initiative (GSI), proposed in April 2022, and the Global Civilization Initiative (GCI), announced in March 2023. Together, these three initiatives represent a comprehensive blueprint for an alternative system of global governance, one that seeks to embed Chinese principles and norms into the international order.

The GSI promotes a vision of 'indivisible security', rejecting 'bloc politics' and 'Cold War mentalities'—a thinly veiled critique of US-led alliances like NATO and the Quad. The GCI advocates for respecting the diversity of civilizations and opposes the imposition of universal values, a clear counterpoint to the Western emphasis on liberal democracy and human rights. The GDI, with its focus on 'peace through development', provides the economic foundation for this new architecture. The underlying logic is that security and prosperity are interlinked, and that China's state-led development model offers a more effective path to both than the Western liberal consensus.

This ideological challenge to the post-Cold War order has not gone unnoticed in Western capitals. The GDI and its companion initiatives are viewed with considerable skepticism, seen not as genuine contributions to global public goods, but as instruments for advancing China's geopolitical ambitions. The fear is that China is leveraging its economic and diplomatic clout to create a parallel system of international relations that is more congenial to authoritarian regimes and less constrained by principles of transparency, accountability, and individual rights. The GDI, in this view, is a Trojan horse for expanding Chinese influence and legitimizing a development model that is decoupled from democratic governance.

#### The West's Fledgling Response

The West's response to this challenge has been, to date, more rhetorical than substantive. The G7's 'Build Back Better World' (B3W) initiative, launched in mid-2021, and its successor, the Partnership for Global Infrastructure and Investment (PGII), along with the EU's 'Global Gateway' strategy, are all explicitly framed as alternatives to China's global outreach. They promise to mobilize hundreds of billions of dollars in private and public capital for high-quality, transparent, and sustainable infrastructure projects in the developing world.

These initiatives rightly identify a key vulnerability in China's approach: the demand in many developing countries for infrastructure that adheres to higher environmental, social, and governance (ESG) standards. They also aim to leverage the West's primary competitive advantage: its deep and liquid capital markets and its large multinational corporations.

However, as of December 2023, these Western initiatives remain largely aspirational. The promised funding has been slow to materialize, and the number of concrete projects on the ground is dwarfed by the sheer scale of China's existing global footprint. The challenge for the West lies in translating its vision of 'values-driven' development into a compelling and practical alternative for developing countries. This will require not only mobilizing significant financial resources but also streamlining bureaucratic processes and demonstrating a genuine commitment to partnership rather than paternalism.

There is also a fundamental philosophical divide. The Western model, with its emphasis on private sector-led growth and stringent conditionalities, can be a difficult sell in countries with weak institutional capacity and an urgent need for basic infrastructure. China's state-led, no-strings-attached approach, while fraught with its own risks, often appears to be a more direct and expedient path to development for governments under pressure to deliver results.

#### The Unanswered Questions of the GDI

Two years into its existence, the GDI's long-term trajectory remains an open question. While its initial reception has been positive, its ultimate success will depend on its ability to deliver tangible and sustainable development outcomes. The 'small yet smart' approach is promising, but it remains to be seen whether it can be scaled up to address the immense development challenges facing the Global South.

Furthermore, the issue of debt sustainability has not been entirely resolved. While the GDI's emphasis on grants is a welcome development, China remains the world's largest bilateral creditor, and its role in multilateral debt restructuring efforts through the G20 Common Framework has been criticized for being slow and opaque. A genuine commitment to sustainable development will require greater transparency and a more proactive approach to resolving the debt overhang that afflicts many developing nations, a significant portion of which is owed to Chinese lenders.

Finally, the GDI's ambition to reshape global governance will inevitably generate friction with the existing international order. The West is unlikely to stand idly by as China seeks to embed its own norms and values into the UN system and other multilateral institutions. The coming years will likely see a period of increased competition and contestation over the principles that should guide global development and cooperation.

In conclusion, as of the close of 2023, the Global Development Initiative is more than just a rebranding of Chinese foreign aid. It is a sophisticated and multifaceted strategy that reflects a new phase in China's engagement with the world. By shifting from the high-risk, high-reward approach of the BRI to a more patient and programmatic focus on sustainable development, China is playing a long game. It is a strategy that seeks to win hearts and minds not through overwhelming displays of economic might, but through the quiet and steady accumulation of goodwill. The West would be wise to recognize the potency of this new approach and to formulate a response that is as strategic, coherent, and compelling as the challenge it presents.

title: Deconstructing the UN SDG Report: Why is "Data Infrastructure" Needed?
excerpt: With the 2030 Sustainable Development Goals perilously off-track, a decade of insufficient progress reveals a fundamental, and fixable, flaw: the world is trying to solve 21st-century problems with 20th-century data infrastructure.
body:
### Deconstructing the UN SDG Report: Why is "Data Infrastructure" Needed?

**Halfway to 2030, the world is failing its own Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).** The latest progress reports, issued as of early 2025, make for grim reading. A decade after their adoption, only 35% of the UN's ambitious targets are on track. Nearly half are progressing too slowly, and an alarming 18% have gone into reverse. The official diagnosis points to a familiar litany of culprits: geopolitical conflict, climate shocks, and a crippling financing gap in the developing world. Yet this narrative, while accurate, overlooks a more fundamental, structural flaw. The global effort to achieve the SDGs is being managed with woefully inadequate information. The world is attempting to navigate a polycrisis blindfolded, and the failure to invest in robust data infrastructure is not merely a technical oversight; it is a primary cause of the strategic drift.

This is not a future risk but a present reality. In February 2025, the abrupt termination of American funding for the Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) sent a shockwave through the development community. This single decision jeopardises the collection of critical data for 39 SDG indicators, particularly those concerning health and gender equality, in the very countries that can least afford it. It is a stark illustration of a system built on fragile financial foundations, a system in which the essential work of measuring progress is treated as a discretionary expense rather than a core investment. To understand why the SDGs are failing, one must first look at the data—or, more accurately, the lack of it.

#### The Anatomy of a Data Deficit

The most significant progress gaps in the SDG agenda are mirrored by the most severe data gaps. Goals concerning gender equality (SDG 5), sustainable cities (SDG 11), climate action (SDG 13), and peace and justice (SDG 16) consistently show the least progress, and it is no coincidence that they also have the lowest data coverage, with fewer than 30% of their trend data being available. These are not minor informational lacunae; they are vast blind spots in areas critical to the promise of the 2030 Agenda. Without reliable data on gender disparities, violence against women, urban resilience, or institutional integrity, policy becomes guesswork. Resources are misallocated, interventions are poorly targeted, and accountability becomes impossible.

The problem extends beyond mere availability to the timeliness of information. In an era of rapid, overlapping crises, policymakers are often forced to rely on data that is years out of date. Even in the developed world, over 40% of SDG indicators in OECD countries are based on old data, hindering the capacity for real-time response. This informational lag means that by the time a problem is accurately measured, the context has already shifted, rendering the proposed solution obsolete. Before the COVID-19 pandemic, from 2015 to 2019, the average country reported data on only 55% of SDG indicators. This deficit is not simply a matter of technical capacity; it is a reflection of political will and investment priorities. The data gaps are not randomly distributed; they are concentrated in areas that are politically sensitive, difficult to measure, and chronically underfunded.

#### The Fragile Foundations of Funding

The chronic data deficit is a direct consequence of a deeply flawed funding model. While international financial support for data and statistics in low- and middle-income countries did rise by about 50% between 2015 and 2022, this growth masks a precarious reality. Funding from traditional development assistance committees has stagnated, with the increase coming from a small number of multilateral organisations, private foundations, and non-DAC countries. In 2022, just nine funders provided roughly 70% of all financial support for data.

This concentration of funding creates systemic risk, as the DHS programme's recent disruption vividly demonstrates. The reliance on external, project-based financing has created a donor-driven ecosystem where national priorities can be subordinated to the interests and reporting requirements of funders. This model actively discourages the long-term, domestic investment needed to build resilient, country-led statistical systems. In low-income countries, over 90% of household surveys planned for the 2024-2025 period depend on external funding. This dependency is untenable. The paradox is that just as the demand for high-quality, granular data has become more acute, the financial architecture supporting its production has been exposed as dangerously brittle. Without a fundamental shift from short-term projects to sustained, systemic investment, the data infrastructure required to guide the SDGs will never materialise.

#### Reimagining the Scaffolding: From Statistics to Infrastructure

A critical conceptual shift is required to address this challenge: data must be treated not as a reporting by-product but as foundational infrastructure, as essential to a 21st-century society as roads, power grids, and sanitation. Just as physical infrastructure enables economic activity, data infrastructure enables effective governance, innovation, and evidence-based policy. This encompasses the entire ecosystem: the collection of raw data from diverse sources like satellite imagery and real-time sensors; the platforms for processing and analysis; the legal and ethical frameworks for governance; and the systems for disseminating insights to decision-makers.

This thinking is gaining traction under the banner of Digital Public Infrastructure (DPI). Championed by institutions like the World Bank and the UNDP, DPI refers to foundational, society-wide digital systems—such as digital identity, digital payments, and data exchange platforms—that can be used by both public and private sectors to deliver services. By creating a set of reusable "digital building blocks," DPI can dramatically accelerate digital transformation and, by extension, progress on the SDGs. For example, a robust digital identity system can facilitate social protection payments (SDG 1), access to healthcare (SDG 3), and financial inclusion (SDG 8). A well-governed data exchange layer can enable targeted interventions for underserved communities (SDG 10) and more efficient urban planning (SDG 11). This approach represents a move away from fragmented, siloed IT projects toward the creation of a resilient, adaptable digital commons that fosters innovation and inclusion.

#### The Double-Edged Sword of Technology

Into this landscape of data deficits and infrastructural needs comes the promise of new technology. Big data analytics and artificial intelligence (AI) offer the potential to leapfrog traditional, resource-intensive data collection methods. AI-driven systems can analyse vast datasets to identify patterns, make predictions, and provide insights that were previously unattainable. Machine learning models can help estimate carbon sequestration to support climate action (SDG 13), track disease outbreaks for public health (SDG 3), and monitor agricultural yields to improve food security (SDG 2).

However, this technological frontier is not without its perils. The uncritical application of BDAI risks creating and amplifying the very inequalities the SDGs are meant to address. Algorithms trained on biased data can reinforce discrimination against marginalised groups. The immense power of these technologies is concentrated in the hands of a few large private corporations, raising concerns about a new form of "data colonialism" where value and insights are extracted from developing nations with little reciprocal benefit. Issues of data privacy, security, and algorithmic transparency are paramount. Without robust public governance and inclusive data ecosystems, the turn to BDAI could further entrench the digital divide and undermine the foundational SDG principle of "leaving no one behind." Technology can be a powerful accelerator, but it is not a substitute for the hard work of building institutional capacity and sound governance.

#### The Imperative of a New Data Compact

Navigating the final five years of the 2030 Agenda demands a new social contract for data. The current trajectory of insufficient progress is, in large part, a trajectory of insufficient information. Rectifying this requires a concerted effort on three fronts.

First, funding for data systems must be scaled up and stabilised. The international community must move beyond ad-hoc projects and commit to long-term financing that strengthens country-led statistical systems. National governments, in turn, must increase domestic investment in their own data infrastructure, recognizing it as a critical component of national sovereignty and development.

Second, new models of collaboration are essential. National Statistical Offices, while central, cannot meet the data demands of the SDGs alone. They must evolve to become orchestrators of a wider data ecosystem, forging partnerships with the private sector, academia, and civil society. Currently, only half of NSOs partner with the private sector, a vast untapped resource. However, corporate engagement must move beyond glossy sustainability reports that are often more symbolic than substantive. A push towards standardized, mandatory corporate reporting on SDG impacts is crucial for genuine accountability.

Third, the development of data infrastructure, particularly DPI, must be guided by principles of inclusion, trust, and public good. This requires strong governance frameworks that protect individual privacy, ensure data security, and promote equitable access to the benefits of the digital economy.

The evidence as of February 2025 is unequivocal: the ambitious goals set in 2015 are at severe risk of failure. The cascade of global crises has undoubtedly made the path steeper. But the lack of progress is also a story of a persistent and critical blind spot. The global community has failed to adequately invest in the foundational infrastructure of the information age. Without reliable data to guide policy, measure progress, and ensure accountability, the Sustainable Development Goals will remain little more than a noble but unrealized aspiration. The question is no longer whether we can afford to invest in data infrastructure, but whether, with only five years to go, we can afford not to.

title: China's VNR Release: Economic Resilience in the Post-Pandemic Era
excerpt: Beneath the triumphant narrative of China's post-pandemic recovery and development goals, a messier reality is unfolding as a deepening property crisis and a sweeping regulatory crackdown reveal the inherent contradictions of its state-led economic model.
body:
### China's Great Contradiction

BEIJING—To read China's latest Voluntary National Review (VNR), submitted to the United Nations in the summer of 2021, is to witness a masterclass in narrative construction. The document, a self-assessment of progress towards the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), paints a portrait of a nation triumphant. Beijing reports that it has eradicated extreme poverty a full decade ahead of the 2030 deadline, a truly monumental achievement. It showcases a country leading a determined charge towards a green future, boosting its renewable energy capacity and committing to ambitious carbon goals. The underlying message, delivered with unflinching confidence, is one of resilience and superior governance. Fresh from being the only major economy to grow in 2020, China’s state-led model, the VNR implicitly argues, has not only weathered the pandemic but has emerged demonstrably stronger.

Yet, for an observer standing in the crisp air of early autumn 2021, this polished narrative jars with a far messier reality. The V-shaped recovery, which saw GDP surge by a staggering 18.3% in the first quarter of the year, was already losing momentum. More worrying are the tremors emanating from deep within the foundations of the economy. The vast and opaque property sector, long a supercharged engine of growth, is groaning under the weight of immense debt, epitomised by the slow-motion collapse of Evergrande, a property giant that began missing crucial offshore bond payments in September. Simultaneously, a sweeping and often brutal regulatory crackdown, unleashed in the name of “common prosperity,” is rewriting the rules for private enterprise overnight, sending shockwaves through the technology, education, and entertainment sectors that had been the most dynamic parts of the economy.

This is the great contradiction at the heart of the world’s second-largest economy. On one hand, there is the state's immense capacity for mobilisation, capable of eliminating poverty, building world-class infrastructure, and containing a pandemic with ruthless efficiency. On the other, there is the inherent fragility of a growth model that remains dangerously dependent on debt-fuelled property development and the rising risk that the state, in its quest for control, will suffocate the very dynamism it needs to secure its future. The official story is one of seamless progress; the truth on the ground is one of high-stakes improvisation in the face of mounting instability.

#### The Engine Room Sputters

China's post-pandemic recovery was, at first, an object of global envy. While the West was mired in lockdowns and stimulus debates, Chinese factories were humming, churning out everything from personal protective equipment to work-from-home electronics for a world in desperate need. This export boom, combined with a torrent of state-directed investment in infrastructure, powered the economy back from its historic 6.8% contraction in the first quarter of 2020. By the end of that year, China had posted 2.3% growth, a singular achievement.

However, this recovery was always unbalanced. It relied on the familiar levers of industrial production and state spending, while the third, and arguably most important, engine—domestic consumption—has struggled to fire. Retail sales have lagged, and household confidence remains subdued. The very policies that enabled the swift reopening, namely stringent, localised lockdowns, have also made consumers cautious. This lopsided recovery, propped up by the state and external demand, is now looking tired.

More concerning is the new strategic direction articulated in the 14th Five-Year Plan (2021-2025). The plan's cornerstone is the “dual circulation” strategy, a rather opaque term for a significant strategic pivot. In essence, Beijing aims to make the economy more reliant on “internal circulation”—the domestic cycle of production and consumption—while “external circulation” becomes a secondary, albeit still important, support. The goal is to build a more resilient economy, insulated from what it perceives as an increasingly hostile external environment, particularly an America determined to decouple. This translates into a massive push for technological self-sufficiency, particularly in critical areas like semiconductors, and a renewed emphasis on strengthening the domestic market.

On paper, this is a sensible long-term ambition. No country of China’s scale wishes to be perpetually dependent on foreign technology or markets. But the timing and execution are fraught with peril. Shifting towards domestic consumption as the primary growth driver is a goal that has been touted for over a decade with only modest success. It requires deep structural reforms: strengthening the social safety net to reduce precautionary savings, liberalising the *hukou* household registration system to boost urbanisation and migrant spending, and, most critically, ensuring that households see a greater share of the economic pie. There is little sign that these difficult reforms are being prioritised over the state’s more immediate focus on industrial policy and control.

#### The Edifice of Debt

The most immediate threat to this strategic pivot, and to economic stability itself, comes from the property sector. For decades, real estate has been the bedrock of China's growth model. It accounts for a significant chunk of GDP, a vast share of household wealth, and the primary source of revenue for local governments, who sell land to developers to fund their operations. This model has created a seemingly endless cycle of construction, rising property values, and debt accumulation.

That cycle is now breaking. In August 2020, regulators, alarmed by the sector's leverage, introduced the “three red lines” policy, which set strict caps on developer debt ratios. This move effectively cut off the flow of easy credit that had sustained highly indebted firms like Evergrande. With liabilities reportedly exceeding $300 billion, the company's predicament is a stark illustration of the sector's systemic risk. Its struggles to meet interest payments have sent jitters through global financial markets and left hundreds of thousands of homebuyers in China wondering if the apartments they have paid for will ever be completed.

As of early October 2021, Beijing's response has been a calculated silence. There has been no official bailout, a clear signal that the era of implicit state guarantees for corporate behemoths is over. The government appears to be orchestrating a controlled demolition, aiming to prevent a chaotic collapse that could trigger a full-blown financial crisis while simultaneously imposing discipline on a reckless industry. It is a dangerous balancing act. A severe downturn in the property market would not only hit developers and banks; it would cripple local government finances and evaporate household wealth, posing a significant threat to consumer spending and social stability.

#### The Party Knows Best

Looming over these economic challenges is a profound shift in the political landscape. The regulatory storm that began with the scuttling of Ant Group's IPO in late 2020 has morphed into a far-reaching campaign to rein in the private sector. Tech giants like Alibaba, Tencent, and Didi have faced a barrage of anti-monopoly fines, data-security probes, and new regulations. The for-profit education industry was effectively wiped out by a policy change over the summer. The campaign’s logic is multifaceted: it seeks to curb the power of tech platforms that have amassed vast amounts of data and influence, reduce social inequalities by targeting perceived excesses in areas like private tutoring and online gaming, and ensure that all centres of power are subservient to the Communist Party.

This reassertion of Party dominance is creating a deep sense of uncertainty. The very entrepreneurs who built China's modern economy are now navigating a new reality where political loyalty and alignment with state goals trump market logic. While proponents argue that this will lead to a more equitable and sustainable development model, the immediate effect has been to chill investment and innovation. The dynamism that came from a freewheeling, if sometimes chaotic, private sector is being systematically curtailed. For global investors, the political risk associated with China has been recalibrated upwards in a way not seen for decades.

China's leaders are betting that they can manage this transition. They believe the state can direct capital and innovation into “hard tech” and strategic industries identified in the Five-Year Plans, replacing the “disorderly expansion of capital” seen in consumer internet platforms. They are betting that a deleveraged, more sober property market will emerge from the wreckage of Evergrande. And they are betting that the narrative of national success, as articulated in the VNR, will be sufficient to maintain public confidence as the economy navigates this turbulent period.

It is a bold and risky wager. The state-led approach may prove effective in mobilising resources for national projects, but it has a poor record globally when it comes to fostering the kind of bottom-up innovation needed to reach the technological frontier. Furthermore, managing the slowdown in property and the shock of the regulatory crackdown without causing a sharp economic downturn will require immense skill. The triumphant tone of China's mid-year report to the world projects an image of a country in full control of its destiny. The reality, as autumn unfolds, looks much more like a high-wire act with no safety net.

title: Corporate Biodiversity Responsibility under the "Kunming-Montreal Framework"
excerpt: As negotiators at the COP15 biodiversity summit in Montreal debate a landmark proposal for mandatory corporate nature-related disclosure, the business world stands at a crossroads between voluntary rhetoric and binding accountability.
body:
### Corporate Biodiversity Responsibility under the "Kunming-Montreal Framework"

**Montreal, Canada – December 12, 2022** – As negotiators in Montreal enter the final, fraught stages of the COP15 biodiversity summit, a new and contentious frontier is opening up for the corporate world. The draft "Kunming-Montreal Global Biodiversity Framework" (GBF) is not merely another environmental accord; it represents a potential paradigm shift in how businesses are held accountable for their impact on the natural world. At the heart of this debate is a single, pivotal proposal: Target 15, which calls for mandatory assessment and disclosure of corporate dependencies and impacts on biodiversity for all large businesses and financial institutions. [5, 13, 14, 23] The outcome of these discussions will determine whether corporate responsibility for nature remains a voluntary, often cosmetic, exercise or becomes a hard-edged feature of the global economic architecture.

For years, the corporate world’s engagement with biodiversity has been a patchy affair, characterized more by philanthropic gestures and glossy sustainability reports than by fundamental changes to business models. The Aichi Targets, agreed upon in 2010, largely failed to galvanize the private sector, and not a single one was fully met. [11] Now, with scientists warning that the planet is experiencing its largest loss of life since the dinosaurs, the stakes are considerably higher. [4] The language of “nature-positive” is gaining currency, but the path from rhetoric to reality is proving to be a difficult one.

#### The Great Divide: Voluntary Pledges vs. Mandatory Obligations

The central tension at COP15, as far as the business world is concerned, is the move from voluntary commitments to binding requirements. On one side, a vocal and growing coalition of over 300 businesses, with combined revenues exceeding $1.5 trillion, is actively lobbying for mandatory disclosure. [5, 13, 14] This group, which includes household names like H&M, Unilever, and Nestlé, argues that a level playing field is essential. [5, 13] Without a common set of rules, they contend, laggards will continue to free-ride on the efforts of more progressive firms, and the systemic risks posed by biodiversity loss will remain dangerously opaque. Their logic is clear: what gets measured gets managed, and mandatory reporting is the first step towards systematic management of nature-related risks.

On the other side, there remains a powerful undercurrent of resistance. While few large corporations would publicly oppose environmental protection, many are quietly lobbying against prescriptive regulations. Their arguments often center on the complexity of measuring biodiversity, the potential for increased compliance costs, and the preference for market-led, voluntary solutions. This camp points to the proliferation of private initiatives and frameworks as evidence that the corporate world can regulate itself. However, the data, as of late 2022, tells a different story. A recent report from CDP, a non-profit that runs a global disclosure system, found that while a heartening 87% of companies responded to new biodiversity-related questions, a staggering 55% had failed to take any action to progress their biodiversity commitments in the past year. [41] Similarly, an S&P Global analysis from November 2022 revealed that only a third of Europe's largest companies have set any biodiversity targets at all, with even lower figures for American and Asia-Pacific firms. [29]

This gap between rhetoric and action is the crux of the problem. While a vanguard of companies sees the strategic advantage of getting ahead of the curve, the majority remain on the sidelines. The failure of the Aichi targets serves as a stark reminder that voluntary ambition, however well-intentioned, has historically been insufficient to drive the scale of change required. [11]

#### The Alphabet Soup of Accountability: TNFD, SBTN, and the Search for Metrics

Parallel to the policy debates in Montreal, a quiet revolution is taking place in the world of corporate accounting and risk management. The Taskforce on Nature-related Financial Disclosures (TNFD), modeled on its successful climate-focused predecessor, the TCFD, is developing a framework to help companies and financial institutions report and act on nature-related risks. [7, 15] Having released beta versions of its framework throughout 2022, the TNFD is attempting to bring the same rigor to biodiversity that the TCFD brought to climate. [7, 15] The framework is structured around four pillars: governance, strategy, risk management, and metrics and targets. [16]

However, the task facing the TNFD is an order of magnitude more complex than that of the TCFD. Climate change, for all its multifaceted impacts, has a single, universally understood metric: tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent. Biodiversity has no such common currency. A ton of carbon emitted in Mumbai has the same atmospheric impact as a ton emitted in Madrid. The value of a hectare of rainforest in the Amazon, however, is not interchangeable with a hectare of mangrove swamp in Southeast Asia. This inherent location-specificity of biodiversity makes standardization a Herculean task. Ecologists themselves often disagree on the most appropriate metrics for assessing the health of an ecosystem. [5]

This measurement challenge is a significant hurdle. Companies argue, with some justification, that they cannot be expected to report on something that cannot be easily and consistently measured. This is where initiatives like the Science Based Targets Network (SBTN) come in. The SBTN is working to develop methodologies for companies to set credible, science-based targets for nature, similar to the now well-established Science Based Targets for climate. [21] Yet, like the TNFD, the SBTN is still in its developmental stages. Its final guidance for companies is not expected until 2023.

The Global Reporting Initiative (GRI) is also in the process of revising its biodiversity standard (GRI 304), with a new draft expected to be released for public comment in the coming months. [27, 33] This flurry of activity from standard-setters is both promising and problematic. It signals a clear direction of travel, but the lack of a single, universally accepted framework creates confusion and allows for cherry-picking of methodologies by companies looking to present their activities in the best possible light.

#### The Financial Sector: From Bystander to Catalyst?

Perhaps the most significant development in the corporate biodiversity debate is the awakening of the financial sector. For decades, biodiversity loss was seen as a purely environmental or ethical issue, a tragic but distant externality. That perception is now rapidly changing. Central bankers and financial regulators are beginning to recognize that the collapse of ecosystems poses a systemic risk to financial stability. Studies have shown that a significant portion of the global economy, and therefore the assets held by financial institutions, is highly dependent on nature. [36]

The TNFD, from its inception, has been heavily focused on the financial sector, recognizing that a shift in global financial flows away from nature-negative outcomes is a prerequisite for any meaningful progress. [7] The draft GBF reflects this understanding, with Target 14 calling for the alignment of financial flows with the goal of living in harmony with nature. Financial institutions are being pushed to not only assess the nature-related risks in their own portfolios but also to use their leverage as investors and lenders to drive more sustainable practices in the companies they finance.

This is where the rubber will truly hit the road. When access to capital becomes contingent on a company’s ability to demonstrate a credible strategy for managing its biodiversity impacts, C-suites will have no choice but to take the issue seriously. However, as with corporations, the financial sector’s journey is just beginning. The tools and data needed to accurately assess nature-related financial risks are still in their infancy. Methodological challenges abound, and there is a very real danger that, without clear and mandatory disclosure requirements, the financial sector's engagement will remain superficial.

#### The Road from Montreal: A Skeptic's Guide

As the negotiations at COP15 reach their crescendo, the mood among seasoned observers is one of cautious, and perhaps cynical, optimism. The unprecedented level of business engagement is a positive sign. [23] The fact that hundreds of major corporations are calling for mandatory disclosure would have been unthinkable a decade ago. [5, 13, 14] Yet, the ghost of past failures looms large. The history of international environmental agreements is littered with ambitious targets that were quietly missed.

The final text of the Kunming-Montreal Global Biodiversity Framework, whatever its wording on corporate responsibility, will not be a silver bullet. If Target 15 is watered down to a voluntary commitment, it will be seen as a major victory for the status quo and a significant setback for corporate accountability. Even if it remains mandatory, the real test will come in its implementation. National governments will need to translate the global framework into domestic legislation, a process that is likely to be slow and fraught with political compromise.

For businesses, the direction of travel is clear, regardless of the precise outcome in Montreal. The era of treating nature as a free and inexhaustible resource is coming to an end. Reputational, regulatory, and financial risks are converging to force a fundamental rethinking of the relationship between commerce and the natural world. The companies that will thrive in the coming decades will be those that recognize this reality and embed biodiversity into their core strategies, not as a matter of corporate social responsibility, but as a fundamental imperative of risk management and long-term value creation. The question that remains is whether this transformation will happen quickly enough to avert the worst of the biodiversity crisis. The signs from Montreal are mixed, and a healthy dose of skepticism is warranted.

title: Policy Seminar on China's Mandatory ESG Disclosure
China's Carbon Emission Accounting Standards and Corporate Emission Reduction
excerpt: As of late 2024, China is rapidly constructing a complex architecture of carbon accounting standards and emissions trading, yet its foundational reliance on intensity-based targets and nascent corporate disclosure practices reveals a critical gap between ambitious climate goals and the on-the-ground reality.
body:
### China’s Great Carbon Ledger: A Work in Progress

**BEIJING**—In the grand theatre of global climate action, China’s performance is pivotal. The country, the world’s largest emitter of greenhouse gases, has committed to the herculean tasks of peaking carbon dioxide emissions before 2030 and achieving carbon neutrality by 2060. As of early November 2024, the architectural blueprints for this monumental undertaking are being rapidly redrafted. A flurry of policy announcements throughout the year has sought to impose order on how the country measures, reports, and ultimately prices carbon. Yet, for all the frenetic activity, the foundation of this edifice—a unified, transparent, and rigorous carbon accounting standard—remains worryingly incomplete. The gap between ambition and the reality of corporate practice is where the success of China’s climate goals will be determined.

At the heart of Beijing's strategy is the national Emissions Trading System (ETS), the world's largest by covered emissions since its launch in 2021. Initially covering only the power sector, 2024 has been a year of significant, if tentative, expansion. In September, the Ministry of Ecology and Environment (MEE) confirmed that the steel, cement, and aluminum sectors would be brought into the fold. This expansion is projected to increase the ETS's coverage from over 40% to approximately 60% of the nation's total carbon emissions, a substantial leap. The Interim Regulations on the Administration of Carbon Emissions Trading, which came into force on May 1st, 2024, provided a more robust legal underpinning for the market, strengthening penalties for non-compliance and data fabrication—a persistent and nagging concern.

However, the ETS, in its current form, is a curiously designed beast. It operates on an intensity-based, not an absolute, cap. Allowances are allocated based on emissions per unit of output (e.g., tonnes of CO2 per megawatt-hour of electricity). This means that a company can increase its total emissions and still be in compliance, provided its efficiency improves relative to a government-set benchmark. For the newly included heavy-industry sectors, allowances will be freely allocated until at least 2027, blunting the immediate financial incentive for deep decarbonisation. While this approach cushions industries and prioritises technological upgrading over production cuts—a clear political choice—it fundamentally limits the scheme's ability to drive the absolute reductions necessary to meet the 2030 peaking goal. Analysts rightly argue this is the system's core weakness, a compromise that trades environmental bite for industrial stability.

#### The Data Deficit

Beneath the architecture of the ETS lies a more fundamental problem: the quality and consistency of the data that underpins it. For a market to function, its currency—in this case, tonnes of verifiable CO2—must be trusted. On this front, Beijing is acutely aware of its shortcomings. In October 2024, the National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC) and other ministries jointly issued a “Work Plan to Strengthen the Carbon Emissions Statistical Accounting System”. This was a clear admission that the existing framework is not yet fit for purpose.

The plan is ambitious, outlining a two-phase approach. By 2025, the goal is to establish a robust data foundation, including annual reporting systems and a national greenhouse gas emission factor database. By 2030, a comprehensive and unified carbon accounting system is envisioned. This follows an August 2024 announcement of a plan to roll out 70 national standards for carbon accounting and footprints by the end of the year. In early November, the Ministry of Industry and Information Technology (MIIT) followed up with guidelines for formulating carbon footprint accounting rules for key industrial products.

This flurry of decrees highlights a critical pressure point: international trade. The plan explicitly prioritises creating carbon footprint standards for new energy vehicles, photovoltaic products, and lithium batteries—the new pillars of Chinese exports. This is a direct response to the European Union’s Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM), which will require importers to pay a price for the carbon embedded in the goods they bring into the bloc. Without a credible, state-backed system for calculating these footprints, Chinese exporters risk being at a significant disadvantage, subject to less favourable default values set by the EU. The race to standardise is as much about trade policy as it is about climate policy.

For corporations on the ground, this top-down push for standardisation presents a formidable challenge. For years, emissions reporting has been a fragmented affair, governed by a patchwork of guidelines for different sectors. A 2022 incident where the MEE publicly called out four firms for fabricating emissions data underscored the persistent issues with data integrity. While compliance rates within the ETS for the power sector have been high, this says more about the generous initial allocation of allowances than the rigour of the underlying data.

#### The Corporate Blind Spot: Scope 3 and Beyond

Beyond the mandatory reporting for the ETS, the landscape of corporate climate disclosure is in its infancy. In April 2024, China's stock exchanges issued their first guidelines on corporate sustainability reporting, which took effect in May. These rules mandate disclosures for certain large and dual-listed companies, with the first reports for the 2025 calendar year due by April 2026. While this aligns China with a global trend towards mandatory ESG reporting, the requirements remain a step behind international best practice.

The most significant lacuna is in the accounting for Scope 3 emissions—those generated in a company's value chain, outside its direct operations. For many industries, this is where the majority of emissions lie. Yet, research from 2024 indicates that only a small fraction—around 22%—of major Chinese listed companies disclose any Scope 3 emissions, and those that do often report on less material categories like business travel, while ignoring the carbon-intensive impact of their core products and supply chains. The new exchange guidelines encourage, but do not mandate, Scope 3 disclosure.

This is a critical blind spot. Without a comprehensive accounting of value-chain emissions, a true picture of a company's climate risk and impact is impossible. It allows for a dangerous form of carbon arbitrage, where a firm can appear to be reducing its own emissions (Scope 1 and 2) while its suppliers continue to pollute with impunity. The government's focus on product-level carbon footprints is a step in the right direction, but integrating this into corporate-level accounting and target-setting is a distant prospect.

In practice, Chinese firms are being pulled in two directions. On one hand, the domestic policy environment, particularly the intensity-based ETS, incentivises incremental efficiency gains in production. On the other, pressure from international investors and customers (and regulations like the CBAM) demands a more holistic approach to decarbonisation that encompasses the entire value chain. Most are ill-equipped for this latter task. The capabilities for robust carbon accounting, particularly for the complexities of Scope 3, are scarce. There is a burgeoning industry of ESG consultants and service providers, but a systemic upskilling is required.

#### The Path to 2030

As of November 2024, China's carbon accounting and corporate reduction framework is a study in contrasts. The ambition is undeniable, and the speed of policymaking is impressive. The state has clearly identified the foundational importance of measurement and reporting and is moving rapidly to build the necessary infrastructure, from the ETS to product footprint standards. The revival of the China Certified Emission Reduction (CCER) scheme in January 2024 also provides a potential avenue for a domestic voluntary carbon market, further embedding carbon as a tradable commodity.

Yet, the system is being built on foundations that are still setting. The reliance on intensity-based targets in the ETS, the persistent questions around data verification, and the vast, uncharted territory of Scope 3 emissions represent significant structural weaknesses. The focus remains squarely on the production side within China's borders, even as its corporations are deeply integrated into global value chains.

The immediate future will be one of managed chaos for Chinese companies. They face a deluge of new standards and reporting requirements. The NDRC’s 2025 deadline for a functioning national emissions reporting system looms large. Businesses will need to invest heavily in internal data management systems and expertise to meet these new compliance demands. For many, this will be a painful, but necessary, transition from viewing carbon as an externality to managing it as a core business metric.

The true test will come after 2025, when policymakers have promised to consider a shift from intensity control to an absolute cap on emissions. Such a move would transform the ETS from a tool for driving industrial efficiency into a genuine instrument of decarbonisation. It would force a much more profound strategic reorientation within China's industrial giants. Until then, the great carbon ledger remains a work in progress. The numbers are being tallied, but their ultimate meaning—and their power to drive real-world emission cuts at the scale required—is still being written.
