Second, a far greater emphasis on transparent, independent, and quantitative monitoring of outcomes is needed. Without a clear and honest accounting of progress, or the lack thereof, the roadmaps risk becoming little more than paper exercises. Finally, APEC economies must find a way to insulate their cooperation on ocean sustainability from the vicissitudes of geopolitics, recognizing that a degraded ocean is a threat to all, regardless of political alignment.

The future of the Pacific Ocean, and the billions of people who depend on it, requires more than just well-meaning reports and elegantly phrased declarations. It demands a new level of commitment, accountability, and collective action that, thus far, has remained tantalizingly out of reach. The APEC Ocean and Fisheries Working Group has charted a course; the critical question is whether its member economies have the political will to truly set sail.

title: Deconstructing the UN SDG Report: The "Vulnerability" of Global Data Systems
excerpt: With the 2030 deadline looming, the UN's Sustainable Development Goals are imperiled not just by slow progress, but by the systemic collapse of the fragile and underfunded global data systems designed to track them.
body:
### Deconstructing the UN SDG Report: The “Vulnerability” of Global Data Systems

**The grand architecture of the United Nations’ 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, with its 17 goals and 169 targets, rests on a foundation not of political will or financial commitment, but of data. Without robust, timely, and disaggregated data, the entire edifice is little more than a set of noble aspirations. The latest progress reports, including the UN’s own 2025 assessment, paint a sobering picture not just of stalled progress—a familiar narrative of unmet ambitions—but of a more insidious crisis: the profound and growing vulnerability of the very data systems designed to measure that progress. This is not merely a technical failing; it is a systemic weakness that threatens to render the SDGs impotent, a reality underscored by recent shocks to the global statistical infrastructure.**

With just five years remaining until the 2030 deadline, the diagnosis is grim. The 2025 Sustainable Development Goals Report indicates that a mere 35% of SDG targets are on track or making moderate progress. Nearly half are progressing too slowly, and an alarming 18% are in reverse. The world is grappling with a global development emergency, with over 800 million people still in extreme poverty and the 1.5°C climate threshold breached in 2024. While there are pockets of advancement—notably in electricity access, internet penetration, and the reduction of some infectious diseases—the overarching story is one of dangerous inertia.

Yet, to focus solely on the pace of progress is to miss the more fundamental story. The true vulnerability lies in the systems we use to track this journey. The mantra of the data revolution for sustainable development, so optimistically chanted a decade ago, is now colliding with a harsh reality: the data infrastructure itself is chronically underfunded, perilously fragile, and susceptible to the whims of a handful of donors. This is the critical blind spot of the SDG project—an implicit assumption that the means to measure would always be there, a utility as reliable as electricity or water. That assumption is now being tested to breaking point.

#### The Anatomy of Data Fragility

The fragility of the global data ecosystem is not a new phenomenon, but it has been brought into sharp relief by a recent, seismic event. In February 2025, the United States Agency for International Development (USAID) abruptly terminated its funding for the Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) program. This decision, a footnote in a major donor’s budget, has sent shockwaves through the development community. The DHS is not just another survey; it is a cornerstone of global development data, providing critical information on health, gender, and poverty for over 90 countries. Since 2015, DHS data has been used for reporting on 39 separate SDG indicators. For some indicators, such as contraceptive use and experiences of sexual violence, the reliance is acute, with over 70% of data points coming from this single source.

The suspension of the DHS program is a stark illustration of the dangers of centralized funding. A staggering 70% of all data aid originates from just nine donors, creating a precarious dependency. Low-income countries are particularly exposed. In the 2024-2025 period, over 90% of household surveys planned in these nations relied on external funding, compared to around 20% in middle- and high-income countries. This financial model is not just unsustainable; it is a strategic liability. It places the world’s ability to monitor its most pressing challenges at the mercy of shifting political priorities and domestic budget battles in a few wealthy capitals.

Beyond these headline-grabbing shocks, a deeper, more chronic malaise affects national statistical offices (NSOs), the bedrock of any credible data system. These institutions are often under-resourced, lacking the technical capacity, infrastructure, and political clout to meet the voracious data demands of the SDGs. A 2023 UN report found that 23% of countries lack over half the necessary budget for their national statistical programs. The result is a patchwork of data availability, with significant gaps in crucial areas. Goals related to gender equality (SDG 5), climate action (SDG 13), sustainable cities (SDG 11), and peace and justice (SDG 16) consistently demonstrate the lowest levels of data coverage, often below 30%. This is not a random distribution; it reflects a systemic failure to invest in measuring the most complex and politically sensitive aspects of sustainable development.

#### The Illusion of Progress and the Persistence of “Data Droughts”

The narrative of progress in data availability itself warrants skeptical scrutiny. While overall SDG data availability has improved since 2015, this masks deep-seated inequalities. Significant blind spots persist. Over 40% of SDG indicators in OECD countries, for example, rely on outdated data, hindering timely policy responses. Furthermore, the lack of disaggregated data—by gender, age, disability, and location—renders the core SDG principle of “leaving no one behind” a hollow slogan. We may know the national average, but the specific challenges faced by marginalized communities remain shrouded in statistical fog.

This leads to what some analysts have termed a “data drought” in critical thematic areas. Despite the urgency of the climate crisis, 47% of climate-related SDG series lack any data whatsoever. For gender equality, only 17% of the necessary data has been generated since 2015. The Asia-Pacific region, a dynamic engine of global growth, exemplifies this paradox: while its overall data availability for SDGs has risen, it lags the global pace on climate action, and data gaps in gender equality and peace and justice remain profound. This is not simply about missing data points; it is about the inability to conduct evidence-based policymaking on the most defining challenges of our time.

The very structure of the SDG indicator framework has been a subject of criticism. With 232 indicators, the framework has been described as an “encyclopaedic” wish list where everything is a priority, meaning nothing is. This complexity strains the already limited capacity of NSOs and can lead to a focus on what is easily measurable rather than what is most important. There is a clear risk of “overburdening national statistical systems,” particularly in low-income countries, which can paradoxically lead to a greater reliance on externally produced and modeled data, further eroding national ownership and statistical capacity.

#### The Geopolitics of Data and the Digital Divide

The vulnerability of SDG data systems is not occurring in a vacuum. It is set against a backdrop of escalating geopolitical tensions, a growing digital divide, and an increasingly fragmented global approach to data governance. The amount of global data is projected to increase more than fivefold between 2018 and 2025, yet the capacity to harness this deluge for the public good is profoundly unequal.

The digital divide, both between and within countries, is widening. This gap hinders the ability of developing nations to integrate into the global economy and to leverage new data sources—so-called “big data”—for SDG monitoring. While the UN and other bodies have championed the potential of big data to fill statistical gaps, the reality is that many governments lack access to adequate data on their entire populations, particularly the poorest and most marginalized. The promise of a data revolution remains largely unfulfilled for those who need it most.

Furthermore, the lack of a unified global framework for regulating cross-border data flows creates uncertainty and risk. As data becomes an increasingly valuable strategic asset, its governance is being contested by competing national and regional interests. This fragmentation poses a significant threat to the collaborative, open-data ethos that underpins the SDG monitoring framework. Without a coordinated international approach, there is a real danger that access to vital data will become increasingly restricted, further hampering efforts to track global progress.

#### A Call for a Paradigm Shift: From Fragile Funding to Resilient Systems

Addressing the crisis in SDG data requires more than simply appealing for more funding, though that is undoubtedly necessary. It demands a fundamental paradigm shift in how we conceive of and invest in data systems. The current model, characterized by short-term, donor-driven projects, must be replaced by a long-term strategy focused on building resilient, country-led statistical infrastructure. This means treating data systems not as a technical afterthought or a charitable cause, but as essential national infrastructure, as critical to a country’s development as its roads, ports, and power grids.

Several key shifts are necessary. First, domestic resource mobilization for statistics must be significantly increased. While many low-income countries face severe fiscal constraints, there needs to be a greater recognition that investing in data is not a luxury but a prerequisite for effective governance and economic management. International partners can support this by aligning their investments with national priorities and by helping to build the institutional capacity of NSOs.

Second, the international community must move towards more predictable, long-term funding mechanisms for data. The Medellín Framework for Action, adopted at the 2024 UN World Data Forum, provides a roadmap for strengthening data systems, but its implementation requires sustained political and financial commitment. The goal should be to create a more diversified and resilient funding architecture, less susceptible to the shock of a single donor’s withdrawal.

Third, there must be a greater focus on data innovation and the responsible use of new data sources. This includes investing in the skills and technologies needed to leverage big data, citizen-generated data, and other non-traditional sources to complement official statistics. However, this must be done in a way that respects data privacy and ethics and does not exacerbate existing inequalities.

Finally, the political profile of data and statistics needs to be elevated. For too long, this has been seen as a niche, technical domain. The SDG progress reports, with their litany of data gaps and funding shortfalls, should serve as a wake-up call to policymakers at the highest levels. The failure to invest in data is a failure of governance, an abdication of accountability, and a direct threat to the achievement of the 2030 Agenda.

The deconstruction of the UN SDG report reveals a discomforting truth. The goals themselves, while ambitious, are not the primary point of failure. The most critical vulnerability lies in the fragile, under-resourced, and perilously dependent systems we have built to measure them. Without a radical and immediate course correction—a move away from a model of statistical charity towards one of strategic investment in resilient data infrastructure—the 2030 Agenda risks becoming an exercise in measuring our collective failure with ever-diminishing accuracy. The clock is ticking, not just on the SDGs, but on the credibility of the data that underpins them.

title: CBAS Ten-Year Report: China's Progress on Sustainable Cities
excerpt: China's state-driven push for sustainable cities, lauded in the recent CBAS Ten-Year Report, masks a troubling reality of top-down planning and technological fetishism that risks creating efficient but brittle urban landscapes.
body:
## China's Urban Leviathan: A Sustainable Model or a Gilded Cage?

**Beijing's pronouncements on eco-cities and sustainable urbanism have grown ever louder, culminating in the recent CBAS Ten-Year Report which paints a flattering picture of progress towards the UN's Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Yet, beneath the polished surface of state-sanctioned data, a more complex and troubling reality is taking shape in China's sprawling metropolises. The state's top-down, technology-driven approach to urban planning risks creating gleaming, efficient, but ultimately brittle and soulless urban landscapes. The question is not whether China can build sustainable cities, but whether it is building cities that are truly sustainable for human flourishing.**

According to the International Research Center of Big Data for Sustainable Development Goals (CBAS), China is well on its way to meeting its urban sustainability targets. The "Big Earth Data in Support of the Sustainable Development Goals: Special Report for a Decade of the SDGs," released in September 2025, asserts that China has achieved or is on track with 60.5% of its 233 SDG indicators as of 2024. The report further predicts that China is likely to meet or come close to achieving SDG 11—Sustainable Cities and Communities—by 2030. On the surface, these figures are a testament to the unparalleled power of a centrally planned economy to mobilize resources and enact sweeping policy changes. Initiatives like the "Beautiful China 2025" blueprint underscore the government's commitment to embedding environmental protection and green development into its national strategy.

Indeed, the tangible outputs of this commitment are visible across the country. The proliferation of new energy vehicles, with a domestic market penetration rate of 52.2% in the first three quarters of 2025, and the extensive retrofitting of existing buildings for energy efficiency are undeniable achievements. The ambitious "Sponge City" program, launched in 2014, aims to mitigate urban flooding and improve water management through green infrastructure, with pilot projects in 30 districts. Similarly, the Low-Carbon City Pilot (LCCP) policy has been shown to improve urban ecological efficiency by an average of 3.0% in pilot cities compared to their non-pilot counterparts. These initiatives, powered by vast state investment and technological prowess, appear to be steering China's urban behemoths towards a greener future.

### The Cracks in the Concrete

However, a more critical examination of China's urban experiment reveals a landscape fraught with challenges and unintended consequences. Despite the optimistic reports, many Chinese cities are still grappling with escalating urban problems, including worsening air and water pollution, chronic traffic congestion, and the persistence of informal settlements. This suggests a significant gap between policy ambition and on-the-ground reality. The slowdown in progress towards the SDGs in some areas raises serious questions about the long-term viability of China's approach.

The very nature of China's state-led urbanism is a double-edged sword. While it allows for rapid infrastructure development, it often prioritizes technocratic solutions over human-centric design. The much-lauded 'smart city' initiatives, for instance, have been criticized for their overemphasis on digital infrastructure and surveillance at the expense of social inclusion and genuine improvements in residents' daily lives. In cities like Chongqing, the promised benefits of data-driven governance have been underwhelming, with persistent issues of inequality and environmental degradation. The focus on grand, top-down projects can also lead to spectacular failures. The Xiong'an New Area, personally championed by President Xi Jinping as a model for sustainable urbanism, has struggled to attract businesses and residents, a stark reminder that even the most ambitious government plans cannot conjure a thriving city out of thin air. The project's shortcomings highlight a fundamental blind spot in China's urban strategy: an underestimation of the organic, bottom-up forces that create vibrant and resilient urban communities.

### The Sponge That Doesn't Absorb

The "Sponge City" program, while conceptually sound, exemplifies the challenges of implementing complex environmental solutions at scale in China. The initiative faces significant hurdles in terms of financing, technological adaptation to local contexts, and regulatory coherence. The abstract nature of the concept has made it difficult to translate into standardized, effective practices across diverse geographical and climatic regions. This has led to inconsistent implementation and raises doubts about the program's ability to achieve its ambitious goals of retaining 70-90% of annual rainwater onsite. The long-term performance data for these measures is still lacking, creating uncertainty for local communities and developers.

Furthermore, the focus on new construction and pilot zones often neglects the immense challenge of retrofitting China's vast existing urban fabric. Transforming these sprawling, concrete-heavy landscapes into permeable, green sponges requires a long-term vision and sustained investment that may be at odds with the short-term political cycles of local officials. Without a more holistic and integrated approach that addresses the complexities of urban renovation and infrastructure renewal, the "Sponge City" initiative risks becoming a collection of isolated showcase projects rather than a transformative national strategy.

### The Eco-City Mirage

The history of China's eco-city movement is littered with cautionary tales. Projects like Dongtan Eco-city in Shanghai, once hailed as the world's first carbon-neutral city, were ultimately abandoned, while others, such as Caofeidian Eco-city, have become ghost towns, monuments to flawed planning and speculative excess. Even relatively successful projects like the Sino-Singapore Tianjin Eco-city have seen their development and population growth lag behind projections. This track record suggests a persistent disconnect between the utopian rhetoric of sustainable urbanism and the pragmatic, often growth-at-all-costs, agendas of local governments and developers.

The term "eco-city" has, in many cases, been co-opted as a marketing tool to promote large-scale real estate developments and attract investment, with little substantive impact on underlying development patterns. This greenwashing not only undermines the credibility of genuine sustainability efforts but also perpetuates the very models of urban sprawl and resource-intensive development that eco-cities are meant to remedy. The lack of robust, independently verified performance metrics for these projects makes it difficult to distinguish between genuine progress and mere propaganda.

### The Data Dilemma and the Path Forward

The CBAS report's reliance on 'Big Earth Data' is both a strength and a potential weakness. While satellite imagery and remote sensing can provide valuable insights into large-scale environmental trends, they can also obscure the granular social and economic realities of urban life. A top-down, data-driven approach to governance, if not balanced by on-the-ground engagement and citizen participation, can lead to policies that are technically sound but socially and culturally disconnected.

To move beyond the current model of state-led, technology-focused urbanism, China needs to embrace a more nuanced and adaptive approach. This will require empowering local communities to participate in the planning and management of their cities, fostering a culture of experimentation and learning from both successes and failures, and developing more sophisticated financing mechanisms to fund long-term sustainability initiatives. A greater emphasis on social equity and the quality of life for all urban residents, including the millions of migrant workers who are often excluded from the benefits of urban development, is also crucial.

Ultimately, the success of China's sustainable cities will not be measured by the number of green buildings or the efficiency of its smart grids, but by their ability to foster vibrant, inclusive, and resilient communities. The CBAS report may signal a step in the right direction, but the journey towards truly sustainable urbanism in China has only just begun. The world will be watching to see if the urban leviathan can learn to walk more softly on the earth.

title: China's VNR and the Chinese Experience in Poverty Eradication
excerpt: China's declaration of "complete victory" over absolute poverty is a monumental achievement in state mobilization, yet a closer look reveals a narrative complicated by a low poverty threshold, questions of financial sustainability, and the persistent challenge of closing the rural human capital gap.
body:
### China's VNR and the Chinese Experience in Poverty Eradication

BEIJING—In late 2020, China declared a “complete victory” in its campaign to eradicate absolute poverty. [19] This announcement, a cornerstone of the centenary celebrations of the Chinese Communist Party, asserts that the final 98.99 million rural residents have been lifted above the national poverty line. [23] According to Beijing's 2021 Voluntary National Review (VNR) on the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, this achievement places China ten years ahead of the UN's global poverty eradication goal. [3] The sheer scale of this endeavor is, by any measure, staggering. The World Bank corroborates the broader narrative, noting that since reforms began in 1978, close to 800 million people in China have been lifted out of poverty, accounting for almost three-quarters of the global reduction in extreme poverty. [18] Yet, as the dust settles on this politically crucial milestone, a more incisive analysis is warranted. The official account, while statistically impressive, warrants a healthy dose of skepticism regarding the definition of “victory,” the sustainability of the methods employed, and the long-term implications for China’s development model.

At the heart of China’s claim is a poverty line set in 2010 at a per capita annual income of 2,300 yuan, which by 2020 equated to roughly 4,000 yuan or about $2.30 a day at purchasing power parity. [2, 16, 24] While this is slightly above the World Bank's international benchmark for extreme poverty of $1.90 per day, it is considerably lower than the $5.50 per day standard for upper-middle-income countries—a category China now firmly occupies. [2] This definitional nuance is critical. While China has indeed won a resounding victory against destitution by one metric, a significant portion of its population remains vulnerable. Premier Li Keqiang himself acknowledged in May 2020 that 600 million people in China still earned a monthly income of barely 1,000 yuan ($140), a figure that, while debated for its methodology, highlights the persistent reality of low incomes for a vast segment of the populace. [2]

The primary engine of China’s multi-decade success has been broad-based economic transformation. [18] For nearly four decades, a rapidly expanding labor market, fueled by relentless GDP growth, did the heavy lifting. [6, 18, 32] This growth story, however, has two distinct phases. The first, from the late 1970s, was characterized by market-oriented reforms, particularly in the agricultural sector, which unleashed productivity and spurred rural income growth. [6, 13] This was followed by the rise of labor-intensive manufacturing, which absorbed surplus rural labor. [18, 32] In this period, poverty reduction was largely a welcome consequence of national economic expansion, rather than its primary, explicit goal. [6]

The second phase, and the focus of the recent official pronouncements, is the era of “Targeted Poverty Alleviation.” Initiated by President Xi Jinping, this strategy marked a decisive shift from broad, area-based approaches to a granular, household-by-household methodology. [4, 9] The state built a national registration system to identify and track impoverished households. [4] This data-driven approach enabled what Beijing refers to as “Targeted Efforts in Six Areas” and “Five Measures for Poverty Eradication,” a suite of interventions including industrial development, relocation from inhospitable areas, ecological compensation, educational support, and social safety nets. [9, 23]

This targeted campaign has been a monumental exercise in state mobilization. The government dispatched hundreds of thousands of cadres to live and work in poor villages, pairing each impoverished household with an official responsible for overseeing its escape from poverty. [19] This top-down, campaign-style approach is a hallmark of the Chinese political system, capable of marshaling immense resources and executing complex logistical feats with an efficiency few other systems could match. [19] Infrastructure, a long-standing strength, was a key component, with massive investments in roads, electricity, and internet connectivity for remote areas. [8, 15] Relocation programs, another significant pillar, moved millions from isolated, mountainous regions to newly constructed villages with better access to services and economic opportunities. [9, 19]

However, the very strengths of this state-led model raise questions about its long-term viability. The immense financial outlay is one concern. Since 2015, the government has spent tens of billions of dollars on direct poverty alleviation efforts. [19] The political imperative to meet the 2020 deadline may have incentivized quick fixes over sustainable, long-term economic solutions. [4] There are reports of local officials, under pressure to produce results, focusing on meeting statistical targets rather than fostering genuine economic independence. The reliance on subsidies and government transfers creates a risk of dependency, and it remains unclear whether many newly non-poor households can withstand economic shocks once intensive state support is withdrawn. A five-year transitional period has been established to consolidate gains and prevent a large-scale relapse into poverty, an implicit acknowledgement of this fragility. [7, 12]

The focus on income and basic needs—the 'two assurances and three guarantees' (food, clothing, compulsory education, basic medical services, and safe housing)—while crucial, has also arguably overshadowed a deeper, more intractable challenge: the rural-urban human capital gap. [3, 23] Critics point out that the campaign did not sufficiently address the quality of rural education. [19] While ensuring school attendance is a laudable achievement, a significant disparity in educational outcomes persists between rural and urban areas. [19] Without a skilled workforce, the economic dynamism of these recently elevated regions is capped, and their populations remain vulnerable as China's economy moves up the value chain and low-skilled jobs become scarcer. [19]

Furthermore, the relocation of entire communities, while improving material conditions for many, comes with its own set of social and economic challenges. Severing ties to ancestral lands and traditional livelihoods can be disruptive. The new settlements, often located on the peripheries of existing towns, require the creation of new, sustainable employment opportunities, which has not always been seamless. The risk is that these communities become isolated pockets of state-dependent populations, physically closer to but not fully integrated into the modern economy.

China’s experience, as detailed in its VNR, is presented as a model for global development. [3] Indeed, the world has much to learn from China's relentless focus, long-term planning, and massive infrastructure investment. [10, 18] The ability of the state to mobilize resources and implement programs at scale is undeniably impressive. However, the exportability of this model is questionable. Few developing countries possess the fiscal capacity or the centralized, authoritarian political structure that underpins China’s approach. [19, 23] The 'institutional advantage' that Chinese media credits for this success is not readily replicable. [19]

Looking ahead, China's challenge shifts from poverty *elimination* to preventing its return and addressing relative poverty and inequality. The 2021 announcement of a new National Administration for Rural Revitalization signals this transition. [7, 12] The focus is now on consolidating achievements and bridging the still-vast urban-rural divide. This will require moving beyond a campaign-based approach to building robust, institutionalized systems of social protection and fostering genuine, self-sustaining local economies. [18] It also necessitates a recalibration of the national poverty line to reflect China's status as an upper-middle-income nation, thereby providing a more realistic picture of economic vulnerability. [18, 26]

In conclusion, China’s declaration of victory over extreme poverty is a significant moment, marking the culmination of an unprecedented four-decade journey. The state’s capacity to identify, target, and materially improve the lives of its poorest citizens on such a massive scale is a testament to its unique governance model. The 2021 VNR rightly highlights this achievement as a major contribution to the global SDGs. However, an incisive analysis must look beyond the headline numbers. The sustainability of these gains is contingent on fostering genuine human capital development and market-based opportunities, rather than perpetual state largesse. The definition of poverty itself invites scrutiny, as the official line masks the reality of low incomes for a large part of the population. China has won a historic battle against absolute destitution. The war to create a truly prosperous society, with shared and sustainable opportunities for all its 1.4 billion citizens, is far from over.

title: China's SDG Index Rank (#49): Achievements and Challenges
excerpt: China's middling rank of 49th in the 2025 SDG Index reveals a nation grappling with the profound contradictions of its development model: a world leader in renewable energy that remains shackled to coal, a conqueror of poverty that faces persistent internal inequalities, and a global power whose international ambitions carry significant sustainability risks.
body:
### China's Sustainable Development Paradox: A Middle Ranking Reveals Deeper Ambitions and Anxieties

**BEIJING** – For a nation accustomed to topping global charts, a rank of 49th is a sobering metric. Yet, this is precisely where China stands in the 2025 Sustainable Development Goals (SDG) Index, a position that belies the monolithic narratives of both its own state media and its harshest critics. With an overall score of 74.4 out of 100, China places firmly in the global midfield, a testament to a development model that has produced staggering achievements alongside deeply entrenched challenges. This ranking, while seemingly unremarkable, offers a crucial lens through which to understand the complex, often contradictory, nature of China's path toward a sustainable future.

At first glance, the successes are undeniable. China has, by its own metrics, achieved the primary target of SDG 1 by eradicating extreme poverty. This feat, which has lifted hundreds of millions out of destitution, is the cornerstone of the Communist Party's modern legitimacy. The state's capacity for mass mobilization is further reflected in its achievement of SDG 4 (Quality Education). These accomplishments are not merely statistical victories; they represent a profound social transformation. However, a deeper look at the SDG dashboard reveals a more complex picture.

While hunger has been largely vanquished, for instance, challenges in nutrition persist, with anemia among women of reproductive age being a notable concern under SDG 2. Similarly, while access to basic drinking water and sanitation has improved dramatically, China still faces significant hurdles in water stress and ecosystem health under SDG 6. These nuances are critical; they illustrate that even in areas of apparent strength, the last mile of sustainable development is often the most arduous.

Nowhere is this paradox more evident than in the environmental sphere. China is, simultaneously, a world leader in renewable energy and a voracious consumer of coal. The country accounts for a staggering 39% of the world's installed wind power capacity and was responsible for 68.21% of newly added global capacity in 2024. This green energy boom is a direct result of state-led industrial policy, a key component of its 14th Five-Year Plan's push for "high-quality development."

Yet, this green revolution is taking place alongside a continued reliance on fossil fuels. Greenhouse gas emissions, a key indicator under SDG 13, remain alarmingly off track. This is the central tension in China's sustainability narrative: a race between its green ambitions and the carbon-intensive engine of its economic growth. The Government Work Report of March 2025 signaled a continued commitment to environmental sustainability, but the on-the-ground reality is a delicate balancing act between economic stability and ecological responsibility.

This balancing act extends to China's urban landscapes. Under SDG 11, China has made commendable progress in providing access to public transport. However, the report also highlights a concerning rise in urban heat-related mortality, a direct consequence of climate change and rapid urbanization. This underscores a recurring theme in China's development: solutions to one problem often create new, unforeseen challenges. The country's top-down approach, so effective in building infrastructure, is less adept at managing the complex, interconnected systems of a modern, urbanized society.

The international dimension of China's SDG performance adds another layer of complexity. The Belt and Road Initiative (BRI), a sprawling infrastructure project, has the potential to export China's development model—and its associated sustainability challenges—across the globe. While the BRI has been praised for its potential to foster economic growth in developing countries, it has also drawn criticism for its environmental and social impacts. The sustainability of these overseas projects will be a crucial test of China's commitment to the global SDG agenda.

Looking ahead, China's forthcoming 15th Five-Year Plan (2026-2030) will be a critical document. It will need to address the persistent inequalities between urban and rural areas, the environmental degradation that threatens to undermine its economic gains, and the need for greater transparency and data availability to accurately track its SDG progress. The current emphasis on "technological self-reliance" could be a double-edged sword. While it may spur innovation in green technologies, it could also lead to a more insular approach to global challenges that require international cooperation.

Ultimately, China's 49th-place ranking in the SDG Index is not a sign of failure, but rather a reflection of the immense scale and complexity of its development journey. The country's ability to navigate the inherent trade-offs between economic growth, social equity, and environmental protection will not only determine its own future but will also have profound implications for the global pursuit of sustainable development. The world has a vested interest in China's success, but a healthy dose of skepticism about the official narrative is, as ever, warranted.

title: CBAS Ten-Year Report: Big Earth Data for Biodiversity
excerpt: A decade of Big Earth Data has revolutionised our view of the planet's biodiversity, yet the torrent of information has so far failed to turn the tide for nature.
body:
## The Digital Ark’s Data Deluge

**A decade of Big Earth Data has revolutionised our view of the planet's biodiversity. But as the CBAS Ten-Year Report shows, the torrent of information is yet to translate into a turning of the tide for nature.**

A decade ago, the notion of monitoring the planet's biodiversity from space, or tasking algorithms with the identification of species from the digital whispers of their calls, belonged more to the realm of science fiction than to practical conservation. Today, as the Chinese Academy of Sciences' (CBAS) notional ten-year report on Big Earth Data for Biodiversity underscores, we are inundated with a deluge of data from a constellation of satellites, a global network of on-the-ground sensors, and the willing participation of millions of citizen scientists. The dream of a digital ark, a comprehensive, real-time inventory of life on Earth, appears tantalisingly within reach. Yet, for all the technological prowess on display, a hard-headed assessment of the past decade reveals a sobering truth: our capacity to collect data has far outstripped our ability to translate it into meaningful, planet-altering action.

The promise, certainly, has been alluring. The fusion of satellite imagery, artificial intelligence, and citizen science has wrought a revolution in how we perceive and quantify the natural world. High-resolution satellite data, once the preserve of intelligence agencies, is now a fundamental tool for tracking habitat destruction and the subtle shifts in vegetation that signal ecosystem stress. Machine learning algorithms, trained on vast datasets of images and sounds, can now identify species with a precision that rivals, and in some cases surpasses, human experts. Platforms like Wildlife Insights, armed with millions of camera trap images, have automated a task that once consumed countless hours of researchers' time. This automation allows for population monitoring on a scale previously unimaginable, providing vital data for tracking the fortunes of endangered species.

Citizen science, meanwhile, has emerged as a formidable force in data collection. Platforms like iNaturalist and eBird have mobilised a global army of amateur naturalists, whose collective observations have filled critical gaps in our understanding of species distribution. This democratisation of data gathering is not merely a quaint exercise in public engagement; it provides a richness and granularity of information that would be prohibitively expensive for professional scientists to collect alone.

### The Corporate Awakening

Perhaps the most significant development of the past decade, however, has been the dawning recognition within the corporate world that biodiversity is not merely a matter for conservationists, but a material business risk. Spurred by the landmark Kunming-Montreal Global Biodiversity Framework, a growing number of companies are beginning to assess their impact and dependency on nature. This has led to a surge in corporate reporting on biodiversity, with a 43% increase in disclosures in the year following the agreement.

This newfound corporate interest has, in turn, fueled the growth of a nascent 'Nature Tech' market. A host of startups are now offering services from AI-powered monitoring of supply chains to the development of biodiversity credit markets. Venture capital is flowing into the sector, with investors increasingly excited about the potential for 'conservation asset markets' that place a tangible economic value on ecosystem services. This alignment of financial incentives with conservation goals is, in theory, a powerful engine for change.

### The Cracks in the Digital Ark

And yet, for all this progress, a healthy dose of skepticism is in order. The CBAS report, while celebrating the technological leaps, implicitly highlights a series of profound challenges that temper the optimistic narrative. The first, and most fundamental, is the persistent gap between data and decision-making. We can now map deforestation in near real-time, but this has not, in itself, halted the chainsaws. The availability of data does not automatically confer the political or economic will to act upon it.

Furthermore, the 'big data' approach to conservation is not without its own set of biases and limitations. There are significant geographical and taxonomic biases in the data we collect. We know far more about the birds of North America and Europe than we do about the insects of the Global South. This 'digital divide' in biodiversity data risks creating a two-tier system of conservation, where the fates of species in less-studied regions are overlooked.

The promise of AI, too, must be viewed with a critical eye. While algorithms can be remarkably adept at pattern recognition, they are only as good as the data they are trained on. Biased or incomplete training datasets can lead to inaccurate conclusions, with potentially dire consequences for conservation efforts. Moreover, the computational power required to train and run these models has its own environmental footprint, a paradox that is often conveniently ignored.

### The Perils of Financialisation

The burgeoning market for biodiversity credits and other nature-based financial instruments also warrants caution. While the intention to channel private finance into conservation is laudable, the history of carbon markets is a cautionary tale. The complexities of measuring, verifying, and ensuring the additionality of biodiversity gains are immense. The risk of 'greenwashing', where companies use the purchase of questionable credits to offset their continued destruction of nature, is very real. The development of robust and transparent standards for these new markets will be critical to their credibility and effectiveness.

Indeed, the push for greater corporate accountability on biodiversity is a double-edged sword. The proliferation of reporting frameworks, from the Global Reporting Initiative (GRI) to the Taskforce on Nature-related Financial Disclosures (TNFD), threatens to create a confusing and fragmented landscape for businesses. While alignment between these initiatives is improving, there is a danger that reporting becomes a box-ticking exercise, rather than a genuine catalyst for change in corporate behaviour.

### The Next Decade: From Data to Impact

The first decade of Big Earth Data for biodiversity has been a period of remarkable technological advancement and a significant shift in awareness. The challenge for the next decade is to bridge the chasm between our newfound ability to see and our collective failure to act. This will require more than just better technology. It will demand a concerted effort to address the systemic barriers to effective conservation.

First, we must move beyond a purely data-driven approach and invest in the human capacity to interpret and act on the information we are gathering. This means strengthening the institutions and governance structures responsible for environmental protection, and empowering local communities who are often the most effective stewards of biodiversity.

Second, we need to be far more critical and discerning in our application of technology. AI and other digital tools should be seen as a means to an end, not an end in themselves. We must be ever-vigilant of their inherent biases and limitations, and ensure that they are deployed in a way that is equitable and just.

Third, the nascent market for nature-based solutions must be developed with the utmost care and integrity. This will require robust regulation, independent verification, and a clear-eyed recognition that not all aspects of the natural world can, or should, be reduced to a financial asset.

Finally, the corporate world must move beyond mere disclosure and embed a genuine concern for biodiversity into its core business strategies. This will require a fundamental shift in mindset, from viewing nature as a resource to be exploited to recognising it as the foundation of our collective prosperity.

The digital ark is under construction, and the data is flooding in. But as the CBAS Ten-Year Report makes clear, simply cataloguing the passengers will not be enough to save them from the coming storm. The next decade will determine whether Big Earth Data becomes a powerful tool for navigating the biodiversity crisis, or merely a detailed record of our failure to do so.

title: China's Industry and Innovation Ecosystem
excerpt: In early 2022, China is making a monumental wager: that its state-led, self-reliance-driven innovation model can overcome inherent inefficiencies and geopolitical pressures to secure its technological future.
body:
### The Leviathan's Lab: China's Wager on Self-Reliance

As of early 2022, China’s industrial and innovation ecosystem presents a Janus-faced spectacle of immense scale and profound insecurity. The state, having nurtured a world-beating digital consumer economy, is now pivoting with force towards a less glamorous but, in its view, more fundamental project: technological self-reliance. This shift, driven by an escalating rivalry with America and a deep-seated conviction that the commanding heights of the 21st-century economy are forged in semiconductor fabs and advanced laboratories, is reshaping the nation's economic landscape. Yet, for all the top-down directives and prodigious spending, a critical question looms: can a state-led innovation model, prone to inefficiency and capital misallocation, truly deliver the breakthroughs needed to secure China's future?

The grand strategy is articulated through a series of interlocking policies. The “Made in China 2025” initiative, though now de-emphasized in official rhetoric due to foreign backlash, remains the foundational text. Its ambition to upgrade and indigenize ten key manufacturing sectors, from robotics to new-energy vehicles, is the thread connecting massive state investments and regulatory guidance. Layered atop this is the 14th Five-Year Plan (2021-2025), which doubles down on “innovation-driven development” and frames self-reliance in science and technology as a matter of national security. This plan explicitly targets frontier areas like artificial intelligence, quantum information, and integrated circuits.

Underpinning this strategic pivot is the concept of “dual circulation,” a framework designed to insulate China from external pressures. First raised by President Xi Jinping in May 2020, it prioritizes the domestic cycle of production, distribution, and consumption, while the “external circulation” becomes a supporting, rather than a primary, driver of growth. This is not an embrace of autarky, but a strategic rebalancing. The goal is to make China's economy less vulnerable to the whims of foreign governments and supply chains, particularly in light of American export controls and sanctions.

#### The Semiconductor Crucible

Nowhere is this quest for self-sufficiency more acute or more challenged than in the semiconductor industry. As of early 2022, China remains critically dependent on foreign technology for advanced chips, a vulnerability that American sanctions against firms like Huawei have painfully exposed. In 2020, indigenous production accounted for a mere 15.9% of the chips sold in China's market, which is the world's largest. The “Made in China 2025” goal of achieving 70% self-sufficiency by 2025 appears increasingly fanciful; one forecast predicts the ratio will only reach 19.4% by then.

The state has responded with a fire hose of capital. The National Integrated Circuit Industry Investment Fund, or “Big Fund,” has poured billions into domestic firms. Yet, the returns have been underwhelming. The industry is littered with tales of failed projects and corruption, a testament to the difficulty of cultivating a complex, capital-intensive ecosystem through sheer political will. Advanced chip manufacturing requires not just vast investment but also deep reserves of tacit knowledge and access to a globalized supply chain for specialized equipment, such as high-end lithography machines, where foreign firms hold a commanding lead.

China's strategy has therefore been a pragmatic, if constrained, one: focusing on mature process nodes (28nm and above) where it can build capacity and gain market share, while pursuing a longer-term, more arduous path towards the leading edge. This has created opportunities for domestic equipment makers to have their machinery qualified by local fabs, a process accelerated by the imperative to design out American components. Still, the gap in critical areas like lithography and electronic design automation (EDA) software remains a chasm.

#### The Great Tech Reckoning

While the state champions innovation in “hard tech,” it has simultaneously taken a heavy hand to the country's most successful innovators: the consumer-facing internet giants. The regulatory storm that began in late 2020 with the scuttling of Ant Group’s IPO has swept across the sector, ensnaring firms like Alibaba, Tencent, and Meituan in a web of anti-monopoly, data security, and consumer protection regulations.

The official justification is to curb the “disorderly expansion of capital,” encourage fair competition, and protect consumer data. There is some merit to this. Like their Western counterparts, China’s tech titans had grown into quasi-monopolies, stifling smaller players and accumulating vast troves of sensitive data. The crackdown, which has included hefty fines and forced restructuring, has reasserted the primacy of the state and sent a clear message that no company is bigger than the Communist Party.

However, this heavy-handed approach carries significant risks. The regulatory uncertainty has chilled investor sentiment and wiped trillions of dollars from the market capitalizations of these firms. Foreign investors, once enamored with the growth story of Chinese tech, are now forced to weigh the ever-present risk of arbitrary state intervention. The crackdown has also diverted the focus of these companies. Once driven by relentless expansion, they are now compelled to align their investment priorities with state goals, channeling resources into areas like semiconductors and AI rather than consumer services. This may serve the state’s strategic objectives, but it is not clear that these historically consumer-focused firms have the institutional DNA to succeed in deep-tech R&D.

#### The State of the Start-up Scene

Paradoxically, even as the tech giants were being reined in, China's venture capital scene had a record-breaking year in 2021, with investments reaching an estimated $130.6 billion. This headline figure, however, masks a crucial pivot. Investment has rapidly shifted away from consumer internet models—online tutoring was decimated by new regulations, for instance—and towards sectors anointed by the state: semiconductors, robotics, enterprise software, and biotechnology. Venture capital is flowing to where the political winds are blowing.

This creates a landscape of government-guided entrepreneurship. While the dynamism of China's startup ecosystem is undeniable, its direction is increasingly being set not by market-discovered needs but by the priorities of the 14th Five-Year Plan. This has led to a surge in funding for companies in favored sectors, but it also raises the risk of bubbles and misallocated capital, as investors chase government subsidies and political favor. The government’s role is pervasive, with local and central government funds being a predominant source of capital for many Chinese VC firms.

The nature of state involvement also shapes the incentives for entrepreneurs. The path to success is often seen through the lens of aligning with national strategic goals, which can foster innovation in targeted areas but may also crowd out more disruptive, bottom-up ideas that challenge established industries or state-owned incumbents.

#### The Ambiguous Role of State-Owned Enterprises

State-Owned Enterprises (SOEs) remain pillars of China’s economy, particularly in strategic sectors like defense, energy, and telecommunications. Historically viewed as inefficient and resistant to change, there is a renewed push to position them as key players in the national innovation drive. Central SOEs have significantly increased their R&D spending and are tasked with making breakthroughs in core technologies.

Their performance, however, is uneven. While SOEs benefit from preferential access to capital and political support, allowing them to undertake long-term, high-risk projects that private firms might shun, they often lack the agility and competitive drive of their private-sector counterparts. The success of mixed-ownership reforms, aimed at improving corporate governance by bringing in private capital, is still being debated. Some evidence suggests that privatization, particularly when domestic non-state capital takes control, can significantly promote innovation.

In strategic areas like high-speed rail, SOEs have demonstrated an ability to assimilate foreign technology and scale it up for the domestic market. Yet, in fast-moving sectors like semiconductors, their record is less impressive. The critical blind spot is whether these behemoths, traditionally focused on execution at scale rather than nimble innovation, can genuinely lead the charge in creating breakthrough technologies from the ground up.

#### The Double-Edged Sword of IP Protection

For years, weak intellectual property (IP) protection was a major complaint of foreign firms operating in China. The landscape is, however, slowly changing. Spurred by its own transition from a technology importer to an innovator, China has been strengthening its IP regime. Recent amendments to patent, trademark, and copyright laws have increased penalties for infringement, and specialized IP courts have been established to handle disputes. The number of IP lawsuits has risen dramatically, indicating that rights holders are more willing to defend their innovations.

This improvement is a double-edged sword for foreign firms. On the one hand, it offers better protection for their own technology. On the other, it reflects the growing confidence and capability of Chinese firms, which are now leveraging the IP system to their own advantage. The strategic goal is clear: to move from being a user of foreign technology to a generator and owner of foundational patents, thereby shifting the global balance of technological power.

#### The Outlook as of Early 2022

China's innovation ecosystem stands at a critical juncture. The state-led drive for technological self-reliance is an audacious, and perhaps necessary, response to a more hostile external environment. The sheer scale of investment in R&D, which is set to grow by more than 7% annually, is formidable. The increasing focus on basic research, with a goal of raising its share of total R&D spending, signals a recognition that true innovation requires foundational scientific breakthroughs.

Yet, the system's inherent contradictions cast a long shadow. The top-down, state-directed approach risks creating a brittle and inefficient innovation landscape, where political priorities trump market logic. The crackdown on the private tech sector, while curbing excesses, has introduced a level of political risk that may deter the very entrepreneurial dynamism China needs. A reliance on SOEs to lead in cutting-edge fields may prove misplaced, and the pivot of venture capital towards state-sanctioned sectors could lead to wasteful subsidy-chasing.

Ultimately, China is making a monumental wager: that it can build an innovation powerhouse that is both state-controlled and globally competitive, insulated from the West yet at the technological frontier. As of early 2022, the resources have been marshalled and the direction has been set. The efficacy of this grand experiment, however, remains far from proven. The Leviathan's laboratory is running at full tilt, but the world has yet to see if it can invent the future.

title: Corporate Transformation Under China's "Dual Carbon" Goal
excerpt: Less than two years after its declaration, China's 'dual carbon' goal is driving a state-mandated rewiring of its economy, yet a closer look reveals a landscape where ambitious policy confronts the hard realities of immature markets, technological hurdles, and the deep-seated inertia of a carbon-based industrial complex.
body:
### Corporate Transformation Under China's "Dual Carbon" Goal

**Beijing** - China's pledge to peak carbon emissions before 2030 and achieve carbon neutrality by 2060—the "dual carbon" goal—is less a gentle nudge towards sustainability and more a seismic, state-mandated rewiring of the world's second-largest economy. Announced in September 2020, this declaration has moved from political rhetoric to the early stages of policy implementation, compelling a corporate transformation of unprecedented scale and speed. Yet, as of mid-2022, a critical examination of the landscape reveals a complex picture of genuine progress, strategic hedging, and significant structural impediments. For corporations, both domestic and foreign, navigating this transition requires a clear-eyed assessment of the emerging policy architecture, the nascent market mechanisms, and the very real technological and financial hurdles that lie ahead.

The central pillar of this transformation is the "1+N" policy framework, a top-level design intended to guide the decarbonisation of key sectors. The "1" represents the overarching guiding opinions, while the "N" signifies specific action plans for crucial areas like energy, industry, and transport. The 14th Five-Year Plan (2021-2025) provides the initial roadmap, targeting an 18% reduction in CO2 intensity and a 13.5% cut in energy intensity relative to 2020 levels. This has sent an unmistakable signal: the era of growth at any environmental cost is officially over. The language has shifted decisively from pollution control to carbon reduction, a more fundamental challenge that strikes at the heart of industrial and energy systems.

#### The Nascent Carbon Market: A Cautious First Step

The most significant market-based instrument deployed to date is the national emissions trading scheme (ETS), which launched its first compliance cycle in July 2021. Covering over 2,000 power generators, it instantly became the world's largest carbon market by volume of emissions covered. The first compliance period, which concluded at the end of 2021, was hailed a success by officials, boasting a compliance rate of 99.5%. Prices for carbon emission allowances (CEAs) remained relatively stable, closing the year up 13% from their opening price and fluctuating in a narrow band around 55-60 RMB per tonne in the first half of 2022.

However, a more critical analysis suggests the ETS, in its initial form, is more of a training exercise than a powerful decarbonisation tool. Several structural weaknesses are apparent. Firstly, trading volumes have been modest, especially when compared to more mature markets like the EU ETS. The vast majority of transactions were over-the-counter block trades, suggesting a lack of liquidity and dynamic price discovery in the open market. Secondly, the allocation of allowances has been generous. Based on an intensity-based benchmark rather than an absolute cap, the system resulted in a significant surplus of allowances in its first compliance period. This oversupply naturally suppresses prices, blunting the financial incentive for deep, structural emissions cuts. Companies can, for now, comply without making painful operational changes.

Furthermore, significant concerns persist around the quality of Monitoring, Reporting, and Verification (MRV) of emissions data. Surveys of market participants reveal this to be a primary challenge, with a lack of transparency and robust penalties for data fraud undermining confidence. Without trustworthy data, the entire market edifice rests on a shaky foundation. The government is aware of these shortcomings and is expected to tighten benchmarks and expand the ETS to other heavy industries like cement and non-ferrous metals. But for now, the carbon price is too low to drive transformative investment in its own right. It is a signal, but not yet a sharp-toothed enforcer.

#### The Corporate Response: From Pledges to Capital Allocation

The response from the corporate world has been bifurcated. At the declarative level, support is widespread. State-owned enterprises (SOEs), in particular, have been quick to align themselves with the national strategy, releasing their own carbon neutrality action plans. As dominant players in the energy and heavy industry sectors, their participation is crucial. However, the true test is not in press releases but in capital expenditure. Here, the evidence is more ambiguous. While there is a clear uptick in green-themed investments, a wholesale pivot away from carbon-intensive assets is not yet fully apparent.

Foreign multinational corporations, often under pressure from their own domestic stakeholders and seeing a new competitive frontier, have been more proactive. Schneider Electric, for instance, has declared China its second-largest market and a key R&D base, increasing investment in localising its supply chains to support the green transition. In the burgeoning new energy vehicle (NEV) sector, foreign giants like Volkswagen are funnelling billions of euros into e-mobility, aiming to compete in a market that has seen explosive growth, with sales ranking first globally for seven consecutive years. These firms see the dual carbon goal not just as a compliance burden, but as a long-term market-shaping reality that creates new and lucrative opportunities.

For domestic firms, particularly in the private sector, the calculation is more complex. The transition demands vast sums of capital for technological upgrades and operational overhauls. While green finance mechanisms are being established, access to this capital is not always straightforward. This creates a challenging environment where companies must balance the political imperative of decarbonisation with the economic realities of a still-developing market for green technologies and the persistent pressure for short-term profitability.

#### Technological Bottlenecks: The Hard-to-Abate Reality

The long-term success of China's dual carbon ambition hinges on technological breakthroughs, particularly in three critical areas: carbon capture, utilization, and storage (CCUS), green hydrogen, and advanced energy storage. As of mid-2022, all three fields are in their infancy, presenting formidable hurdles.

**CCUS:** While identified as an indispensable technology for decarbonising hard-to-abate sectors like steel and cement, CCUS deployment in China remains modest. By the end of 2021, only around 16 projects were operational with a capture capacity of just over 2 million tonnes per year—a tiny fraction of the nation's industrial emissions. The primary obstacle is cost. The expense of capture, compression, and transportation makes most projects economically unviable without significant government subsidies or a much higher carbon price. While several more projects are under development, and the principal use of captured CO2 for enhanced oil recovery (EOR) provides a potential revenue stream, the technology is far from being a scalable, nationwide solution.

**Green Hydrogen:** China's national hydrogen strategy, released in March 2022, is notably conservative, prioritising a colour-agnostic approach for the short term and only envisioning a dominant role for green hydrogen after 2030. This cautious national stance is at odds with the aggressive targets set by provincial governments, particularly in renewable-rich regions like Inner Mongolia, which aim to produce multiples of the national 2025 target. This disconnect highlights a key challenge: while China has the potential to become a leader in electrolyser manufacturing, the cost of producing green hydrogen remains 3-5 times higher than that of grey hydrogen derived from coal. Furthermore, a mismatch exists between the renewable energy resources in the north and west and the hydrogen demand centres in the east, necessitating the development of extensive and costly pipeline infrastructure that is currently lacking.

**Energy Storage:** The rapid expansion of intermittent renewable energy sources like wind and solar necessitates a massive build-out of energy storage to ensure grid stability. The 14th Five-Year Plan calls for the installed capacity of new energy storage to exceed 30 million kilowatts by 2025. Lithium-ion batteries currently dominate the market, and shipments are growing at a torrid pace. However, the industry faces challenges, including rising lithium prices and the need for more mature business models to ensure profitability. While other long-duration storage technologies like compressed air and flow batteries are being explored, they are at an even earlier stage of commercialisation.

#### Regional Tensions and the Central-Local Government Dynamic

A critical, and often overlooked, blind spot in many analyses is the potential for friction between the central government's ambitious climate targets and the economic development priorities of local governments. China's political economy is characterised by a dynamic of "political centralisation and fiscal decentralisation," where local officials are tasked with implementing central mandates while also ensuring local economic growth and employment.

Historically, this has led to a focus on energy-intensive heavy industry as a reliable driver of GDP. The dual carbon targets directly challenge this model. Provinces heavily reliant on coal and traditional industries face the daunting task of economic restructuring, which could lead to unemployment and social instability. This creates a powerful incentive for local governments to protect their economic base, potentially leading to lax enforcement of environmental regulations or continued investment in carbon-intensive projects under the guise of ensuring energy security. The significant regional disparities in economic development and carbon intensity mean that a one-size-fits-all approach to decarbonisation is unworkable. Successfully managing this transition will require not just top-down mandates, but also sophisticated policy design that provides local governments with the resources and incentives to pursue green development pathways.

#### The Path Forward: An Era of Creative Destruction

For corporations, the period leading up to 2030 will be one of profound uncertainty and opportunity. The direction of travel is clear, but the pace and specific contours of the path are still being defined. The dual carbon goal is not merely an environmental policy; it is a fundamental industrial strategy designed to position China as a leader in the green technologies of the future. This will unleash a wave of creative destruction, rewarding firms that can innovate and adapt, while punishing those that cling to the carbon-intensive models of the past.

Several key implications are already apparent. Firstly, supply chains will be reshaped. Companies will face increasing pressure to track and reduce their Scope 3 emissions, forcing a greater degree of collaboration and transparency across entire value chains. Secondly, the demand for green finance will be enormous, creating opportunities for financial institutions to develop innovative products and services. Thirdly, the war for talent in green-tech sectors will intensify. Finally, the role of digital technology—in optimising energy efficiency, managing smart grids, and providing accurate carbon accounting—will become even more critical.

Ultimately, China's corporate landscape is being irrevocably altered by the dual carbon mandate. The initial phase, visible up to mid-2022, is one of policy mobilisation and market experimentation. The policy signals are strong, but the market mechanisms are still immature and technological readiness remains a significant constraint. The transformation is real, but it will not be linear or painless. Success will require more than compliance; it will demand strategic foresight, technological agility, and the courage to invest in a decarbonised future that is rapidly taking shape.

title: Synergy Between China's Green Finance and Climate Action
"Dual Carbon" Goal and China's Carbon Market
excerpt: Two years after China's ambitious "Dual Carbon" pledge, its national carbon market—the world's largest—is operational but lacks teeth, hobbled by a soft, intensity-based design and a surplus of free allowances that keep prices too low to drive meaningful change.
body:
### China’s Carbon Market: A Paper Tiger?

BEIJING—Two years after President Xi Jinping’s landmark pledge to see China’s carbon emissions peak before 2030 and achieve neutrality by 2060, the principal tool designed to meet this audacious goal—a national emissions-trading scheme (ETS)—is struggling to prove its mettle. Launched in July 2021, the ETS instantly became the world’s largest carbon market by volume, regulating the annual emissions of over 2,100 power companies, which collectively account for roughly 4.5 billion tonnes of CO2. Yet, as the market concluded its first compliance cycle at the end of 2021, a searching examination of its design and performance raises a critical question: is this sophisticated new mechanism a true catalyst for decarbonisation, or merely a tentative first step, constrained by the very industrial logic it seeks to transform?

From a distance, the scale of the undertaking is impressive. The scheme covers about 40% of the nation’s emissions from the outset, a share that dwarfs other carbon markets. The stated intention is to use market forces to find the most cost-effective path to emissions reduction, a textbook solution for a continental economy still wrestling with the dual imperatives of growth and environmental stewardship. The first compliance cycle concluded with a reported 99.5% compliance rate, a statistic that officials were quick to trumpet as a resounding success.

However, a closer look beneath the headline figures reveals a system deliberately designed for a soft landing, one that prioritises stability over shock therapy. The core of the issue lies in its architecture. Unlike the cap-and-trade systems of Europe, China’s ETS is intensity-based. Companies are not given a hard cap on their absolute emissions. Instead, they are allocated a volume of free permits based on their output (megawatt-hours of electricity generated) and government-set benchmarks for emissions intensity (tonnes of CO2 per megawatt-hour).

This design has profound implications. A power plant that becomes more efficient than its assigned benchmark can sell its surplus allowances. One that is less efficient must buy allowances to cover its deficit. This, in theory, rewards efficiency. However, it does not prevent a company from increasing its absolute emissions. If a firm doubles its power output—and China’s demand for energy is far from peaking—its emissions allowance doubles too. So long as its rate of emissions per unit of output meets the benchmark, it incurs no penalty. This fundamental characteristic means the ETS, in its current form, is a tool for improving energy efficiency, not necessarily for capping or reducing the total volume of greenhouse gases being sent into the atmosphere.

#### The Generosity of the State

Compounding this structural softness is the generous allocation of allowances in the first compliance period. Benchmarks were set at levels that even moderately efficient coal-fired power plants could meet without significant operational changes or new investment. Indeed, analysis suggests that the vast majority of coal plants received enough free allowances to cover their needs. The result was a market awash with permits and, consequently, a stubbornly low carbon price. When trading began, the price hovered around 48-50 yuan ($7.60) per tonne, a fraction of the prevailing price in the EU’s ETS at the time, which often exceeded €80.

This low price signal is too weak to meaningfully influence corporate behaviour. It does not make high-emitting assets prohibitively expensive to run, nor does it make substantial investments in renewable energy or carbon-capture technology a compelling financial proposition. The market’s trading patterns during its first year underscore this point. Activity was sparse for months, followed by a frantic rush of transactions in the final quarter of 2021 as companies moved to balance their books before the compliance deadline. This suggests the ETS is viewed less as a dynamic market for a valuable commodity and more as an annual administrative hurdle. True price discovery, driven by scarcity and a diverse set of market participants actively hedging and trading, has yet to materialise.

Officials at the Ministry of Ecology and Environment (MEE), which runs the scheme, appear to be playing a long game. The priority for the initial phase was to establish the basic infrastructure of a national carbon market: the registries, the trading platforms, and, most critically, the habits of monitoring, reporting, and verification (MRV) of emissions across thousands of enterprises. From this perspective, the first cycle was about building the scaffolding, not testing the integrity of the structure itself. Issues with data quality have been openly acknowledged as a key challenge, and instilling discipline in this area is a formidable task in its own right.

#### The Spectre of Energy Security

This cautious approach is not merely technocratic. It is deeply political, reflecting Beijing’s overriding concern with energy security and economic stability. The power shortages that gripped China in the summer and autumn of 2021 served as a stark reminder of the country’s continued dependence on coal, which still accounts for over 60% of power generation. Those blackouts, caused by a mismatch between surging post-pandemic industrial demand and insufficient coal supply at fixed electricity prices, solidified a narrative among policymakers that the energy transition must be managed with extreme care. A senior official warning against “campaign-style” carbon reduction policies captured the prevailing mood: climate goals cannot be allowed to jeopardise the functioning of the real economy.

In this context, an intensity-based ETS with generous free allocations is a pragmatic, if environmentally unambitious, choice. It avoids imposing heavy immediate costs on the coal-power sector, the bedrock of the country’s energy system, while gently nudging it towards greater efficiency. It socialises the concept of carbon pricing without triggering the economic disruption that a hard, absolute emissions cap might. The policy is a reflection of China’s broader strategy: to reduce its carbon intensity per unit of GDP, allowing emissions to continue rising in the short term to support economic growth, before a planned peak around the end of the decade.

#### The Path Forward: Incrementalism or a Step Change?

The critical question, as of late 2022, is how and when the ETS will evolve. The MEE has signaled its intent. The next steps involve a gradual tightening of the emissions benchmarks for the power sector. A draft plan for the second compliance cycle (covering 2021 and 2022 emissions) indicates that these benchmarks will indeed be lowered, which should begin to create more scarcity in the market.

Expansion to other sectors is also on the horizon. Heavy industries such as cement, steel, and aluminium are the next candidates for inclusion. Integrating these sectors, which have complex industrial processes and different economic pressures, will be a significant challenge. It will, however, be essential if the market is to have a broader economic impact.

Furthermore, there is growing anticipation for the relaunch of the China Certified Emission Reduction (CCER) scheme. This voluntary offset market was suspended in 2017 due to concerns over low trading volumes and poor standardisation. Its revival is expected soon. CCERs would allow covered entities to meet up to 5% of their compliance obligations by purchasing credits from projects like renewable energy farms or afforestation. This would introduce a crucial element of flexibility and could help stimulate investment in green projects outside the scope of the main ETS. But it also carries the risk of depressing the main allowance price if the offset credits are cheap and plentiful.

Ultimately, for the ETS to become a transformative policy tool, it must move beyond its current design. Three fundamental changes will be necessary, though they are unlikely to be imminent.

First, the introduction of allowance auctioning. Freely allocating 100% of permits mutes the carbon price and forgoes a potential stream of government revenue that could be used to fund the green transition. Phasing in auctions, even for a small percentage of allowances, would improve price discovery and force companies to internalise the cost of carbon more directly.

Second, the inclusion of financial participants. The market is currently restricted to the covered emitters. Allowing banks, brokers, and other financial intermediaries to participate would significantly increase liquidity and create a more sophisticated market for risk management. However, Beijing remains deeply cautious about financial speculation, and is likely to tread carefully.

Third, and most importantly, the eventual shift from an intensity-based target to an absolute cap on emissions. This is the Rubicon that the ETS must cross to align fully with the country’s 2030 peaking goal. A declining absolute cap provides the certainty that total emissions will fall, year on year, creating the predictable scarcity needed for a robust and rising carbon price. This would send an unequivocal signal to all parts of the economy to accelerate the transition away from fossil fuels.

China’s carbon market is a product of the state that created it: immense in scale, methodical in its rollout, and pragmatic to a fault. It has successfully established a nationwide carbon-pricing infrastructure where none existed before. Yet its initial design reveals a deep-seated reluctance to impose costs that could disrupt industrial production or compromise energy security. The high compliance rate of the first cycle speaks more to the modesty of its ambition than to its immediate environmental impact. The "dual carbon" goal is a marathon, not a sprint. But without a more stringent carbon price to drive real abatement, the ETS risks being a tiger that has been declawed, leaving China to rely on its more traditional tools of state-led industrial policy to do the heavy lifting of its energy transition.

title: CBAS Data Analysis: 60.5% of China's Sustainability Indicators On Track
